author: {'steamid': '76561197975257818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1364, 'last_played': 1709694813}
review: This game is an awesome experience in VR, really well adapted. You can orient yourself better and look around objects easier and it's just so relaxing being in those worlds and seeing more detail and scale. Most relaxing and chilled out VR game! You'll need your "VR legs" because there's lots of walking. Thank you Croteam for going to the effort to make this a VR game. I bought the original but didn't finish it on flat screen, later on I got VR and got inspired to finish the whole game in VR. It inspired me to get Talos Principle II, which I'm loving so far (please make that VR also!).

author: {'steamid': '76561198134219338', 'num_games_owned': 1038, 'num_reviews': 768, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1708739981}
review:
Feels like a scam when developers charge full price for a standalone purchase VR port of a non-VR game instead of adding a VR mode to the existing game, but I am a fan of puzzle games and I am a fan of VR so I wanted to check this out.

The ambiance and music are nice and I appreciate a first person puzzle game that isn't trying to directly copy portal, but the story is just a haughty biblical voice that feels like some sacrilegous uncanny valley because they are obviously going for a diety but they wrote it like it was straight out of the holy book itself. My favorite aspect of games is the sense of exploration, which I think is what they were going for here, but for me it turned into hunting for puzzle elements and mechanics, which is probably a lot more tolerable not in VR. It's cool to feel your way through a puzzle and really engage with spacial puzzle solving, but so much is ocluded on every level that it takes more time rooting around to discover the puzzle elements and hazards than it does to mechanically solve the puzzle. There is so much shrubbery and shadows around the castle ruins that it is hard to find anything, and turning a corner into a laser or bomb will reset so you have to take it cautiously, I'm not saying that everything needs to be sterile lab theme but it's just obnoxious to have to have extraneous corridors in puzzle and put puzzle elements out of sight around a corner just so you have to go find and grab them and bring them into the puzzle every level before even starting rather than being able to see the puzzle elements clearly.

On world 4 there is a new puzzle mechanic that appeared just as a shadow on the ground that I couldn't interact with, so I looked around thinking it needed to be activated somehow. Nothing in that stage, so I looked in the other stages in the world thinking maybe I had to do one of the others first like a tutorial for the new mechanic, but they just had ghosts of the object too. So I wandered around the outer area of world 4 searching for anything, and found nothing. Finally looking it up I had to go back to the hub area and UNLOCK the "connector" from the hub area, why???? There is no opportunity for me to have used this piece before world 4, and it's not like you can take it out into the overworld, the necessary pieces spawn in each puzzle, if it's how they wanted to lock progression why not lock world 4 from being entered? On the next world there is a multi-stage puzzle that involves toggling a lot of gates in a sequence multiple times which requires a lot of movement, so after traversing the stage multiple times I reached the final part of the puzzle which was blocked by a pair of orbs that need to be offset which requires undoing the whole puzzle to offset them and the redoing the entire thing. It was possible to see this from the start, and to prevent the backtracking if you ALREADY KNOW how the solution to the puzzle, otherwise the visual obstruction of this feels like a "gotcha" and in VR my tolerance for backtracking is lower. This is just one example of how this is a good port but the game itself is not made for VR and that hinders the experience.

Obviously I'm struggling with things that have not a problem for others, but I wanted to report on the obtuse edges that I was grinding up against in this game. I find it hard to believe that the positive reviews from this game aren't just from people who enjoyed the non-vr version and bought but only played a little of the VR version, since the achievement for activating the elevator after chapter 1 (of 5) only has 10% global completion. I would suggest playing the non-vr version instead of VR but I've played better first person puzzle games than this so personally I wouldn't suggest the non-vr version either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025679656', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1860, 'last_played': 1706750996}
review: Amazing, wonderful, beautiful.  I didn't know what to expect.  I had played a little before but didn't have my VR legs, and the scenery and tools looked a little bland.   Decided to give it another go as I always planned to come back and I was blown away how good this game is.   The puzzles are portal-esque I guess to give some sort of idea but definitely different.   A lot of the puzzles were real brain-busters.   Many I spent half hour one figuring it out.  Some I had to sleep on and come back to.   Many times I thought the puzzles were impossible and/or must have had a bug where the game didn't give me enough lasers or cubes or other tools.  But eventually they all were deemed solvable on their own and I really appreciated the level designers for coming up with such amazing puzzles.  Kudos to them.  And the fact that this is not just puzzles but has a real existential almost quasi-religious take made it so I wanted to finish the game even though I was puzzled out.   Definitely a 10/10 game.   Brilliant!  Can't wait to try the DLC and sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970218572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1707780343}
review: Using a Quest 3. I can say I loved the original for PC, VR is a cool spin off. Definitely a port over. Wish the controls could be changed for the VR controllers. Also grabbing objects seems like you have to reach really far out to grab and drop (little annoying).

review:

Leider kann man in VR nicht einstellen, dass man im Sitzen spielt und somit die HÃ¶he z.B. an den aufzufindenden Computern nicht klappt. Schade auch, dass die Programmierer hier keine Abhilfe schaffen wollen, obwohl diese Einstellung im Rahmen der Barrierefreiheit ein leichtes sein dÃ¼rfte.

Dennoch ist das Spiel echt groÃŸartig, sieht noch immer ganz passabel aus und die Erfolgserlebnisse, wenn man wieder mal ein Puzzleteil erreicht hat, sind einfach groÃŸartig.

Wenn ihr RÃ¤tsel mÃ¶gt: kaufen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024963939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 759, 'last_played': 1708740821}
review: Worth playing past the first parts. After I first got this I never played very far into it, since the first sections seemed repetitive, basic, not very interesting. All that picks up before long. It has more variety than it looks like at first or from the video clips, puzzles and writing get better, etc. Starting Talos 2 and enjoying the example puzzles there that were previews of what this game builds up to is what led me back to trying it out. Shame that Talos 2 doesn't have a VR version (...yet?), but in the meantime I'm enjoying this before I got any further in the new one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084055590', 'num_games_owned': 2877, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1107, 'last_played': 1701987585}
review:
First of all I should mention that I had weird color bugs. If you have the same problems, try to adjust graphic settings and/or switch to DirectX12 or Vulkan.

Anyways, I thought I would like this game. It looked nice and I actually like puzzles too (sometimes;-)). The puzzles are not too complicated and you unlock more elements/tools over time. This should keep you playing, but over the last few days I've had to force myself to keep playing it for a while and I've now reached a point where I'm finally too bored and will probably never finish the game. I can't even put my finger on what it is...the story, the puzzles themselves, or the world. Portal was awesome, qube was ok - story could have been better, but every other puzzle game could get me to finish - not this one.
Maybe I should have tried the normal version first and the VR version later....I really don't know.

Be sure to try it out before you buy it because it's not for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198333727513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2707, 'last_played': 1710554450}
review: For puzzle game lovers, this may be the ultimate. Beautiful, stable, huge . . . unique, distinctive, and consistent in style and theme. And most importantly, the challenges (logic, geometry, order of events) are all in the sweet zone between too hard and too easy. Altogether, a timeless class act. But you do have to love puzzle games, since there's no combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327896269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1954, 'last_played': 1703718988}
review:
I love games like Myst, Obduction, Xing: The Land Beyond, Robinson: The Journey, Wanderer, and Eye of The Temple.
I had read many, many reviews saying that Talos Principle was a great game, but when I looked at screenshots and watched teaser videos, it just didn't look like something I would enjoy.  But one day I was desperate for a new game, and downloaded it.  And I absolutely love it!  
I have really liked how the early puzzles start our simple, and gradually add new complexities, and eventually become quite complex.  But they are still solvable after a lot of thought, and it is so satisfying when I figure out a tough one!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981180543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 6430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6430, 'last_played': 1699582335}
review:
If a puzzle game had a baby with a Sam Harris podcast.

I played this game back in 2017 and loved it.  I'm a huge puzzle fan and I think this might be my favorite puzzle game. It has some really fierce competition, but this game scratched all the right itches. It's got a cool existential story, it's got robots, it's got puzzles, and it's challenging. I've listened to a lot of talks, podcasts, and discussions on AI, free will, existence and meaning, and this game does a great job of actively making me question these concepts. It also does a surprising job at making me think about life and death and I found myself choked up a few times when reading something and applying it to my own life.

It's been six years since that time and I never really thought about a sequel. Somehow it flew under my radar. Two weeks prior to launch of the sequel, it popped up in my newsfeed. I immediately bought the sequel. I then decided, let me watch a recap video in case it's relevant. A minute into the recap video, I decided I needed to replay the game. I very rarely replay a game or rewatch a show/movie, so that's a big deal to me.

I am very glad I decided to. This game stands the test off time. And while it's a VERY basic VR port and has no VR gimmicks other than being VR and picking things up, it's such an awesome way to experience a 3D puzzle game. The game is every bit as fun and challenging as I remember. I don't remember the puzzles, but I did retain the out of the box thinking required for this game. It's not the hardest, not by any stretch. It's moderately hard, even on it's most challenging levels, but it's very rewarding when I would solve a challenge that had me scratching my head.

For the most part, the base game is pretty straight forward and it's easy enough. Road to Gehanna is where the real challenge begins. And it has a really cool story and way of interacting with the world.

For the VR version, some things worth noting:

1. My one trackpad (Vive) didn't always go fast enough, not sure if it's an issue with my controller or the game. But I started using both and it assured I was always going max speed. There is also an option to go max speed all the time, which isn't ideal, but can also solve the issue.

2. If the game tells you this, I sure didn't notice it. But holding both jump buttons (grips on Vive) speeds up the game a lot and makes certain tasks bearable. It obviously mutes the volume, so you could potentially miss some dialogue, but since dialogue is scarce and mostly predictable, you kinda know when not to do it.

3. If you are having difficulty with some jumps, make sure your speed is set to max. You can also try toggling to teleport for certain jumps. I'd say this is really only necessary for easter eggs.

4. Some easter eggs are gone for the VR edition. Others, I couldn't get because of platforming difficulty. I don't think you can go as fast as the non-VR version. I wish they had planned better for this. I was halfway through an easter egg guide when I started to encounter ones I couldn't complete and I got frustrated and stopped.

5. In Road to Gehanna, I was stuck for over an hour on one star because, at least with my setup, the solution was basically impossible. It required a degree of precision that made it seem like this wasn't the solution, and I was just tricking the game, which you can do sometimes. So I moved on and looked for other solutions. Coming back to this one several times. Finally I managed to get it to work. I corroborated my solution with others online and this appears to be the correct solution. A little frustrating, but mostly the game was ported to VR well.

I highly recommend this game, sale or no, it's worth every penny. The first time around it took me about 60 hours to get 80% achievements and everything. This time, it took me around 50 hours and I think I got one more achievement (82%).

author: {'steamid': '76561198050530534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1699627279}
review: This cures depression

author: {'steamid': '76561198009064701', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1652477776}
review:
This game really surprised me, what a fantastic puzzle game. The puzzles are fun, the world is beautiful and the story really compelled me to keep going through the game. The story explores philosophy and religion in a way that challenges and respects the subject. I definitely recommend this game, especially If you like puzzle games like Portal

This addition of being in VR is fantastic and makes it very immersive. There are some beautiful levels in the game so it's great to be able to be surrounded by them and to view them in even more detail!

author: {'steamid': '76561198229037512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1968, 'last_played': 1696701946}
review: the controls are admittedly not the best, but its fun to see these puzzles in VR. at the end of the day if you just want a good puzzle game stick with the original, A VR release is definitely more Niche, but if you are a VR Junkie... Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041768252', 'num_games_owned': 902, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1701446266}
review: awesome game, simple but functional vr port. this is my first/only way im playing the game and its hard to imagine it any other way tbh, I really hope the sequel also supports vr!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971663451', 'num_games_owned': 4413, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2055, 'last_played': 1615473761}
review: Quite nice, played the main game flat and Gehenna in VR. This could definitely use a VR remaster though to bring it up to more modern standards, especially to improve how one interacts with puzzle objects, Another thing would be to enhance world elements such as stone walls to provide more depth and detail/variation so this could be an even more pleasant world to walk around in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960454292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1691537678}
review:
Game is ok, way too large of areas to traverse and lots of back and forth and the directional controls (at least on the knuckles controller) are awful.  You MUST disable the trackpad on the left stick or the Forward direction is constantly changing.  Sometimes forwards is pulling back! on the stick... after you turn off the trackpad the directional control is still awful the way its implemented. 

The game itself is pretty simple, walk aound and solve puzzles.  Its just all the moving around with awful controls that is tedious and a waste of the players time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198981453757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1683837820}
review: puzzle games need to stop with tetris puzzles loved the game until it was just tetris puzzles. you will spend most of the game moving/ moving when you don't want to/ and readjusting your character. play the witness instead more and better puzzles. more puzzles less walking this should be a puzzle game not a walking sim. this is a great game with a cool story and scenery but the vr mechanics cant be over looked. i can not recommend vr version until controls are improved

author: {'steamid': '76561199156520910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2729, 'last_played': 1700947725}
review:
For me a must have for the VR experience.

First off I am not a true gamer or flight sim player. 
I got a Reverb G2 headset and was desperate to get games that used â€œrealisticâ€ backgrounds and scenery; I was actually waiting for the VR release of Myst. I got The Talos Principal on special offer mainly because of the way it looked and I was not disappointed. 

It is a puzzle game, where you have to work out how to use objects and move yourself to achieve the possession of a Tetris like piece: having enough of these pieces, and fitting them together correctly, allows you to progress. Each challenge should only take a few minutes. Sounds simple, but some of the individual puzzles are quite difficult and there are many, many of these, with all sorts of different equipment and environments. There are also hidden â€œstarsâ€ in each game level, which take some hunting to find. So thatâ€™s the game.

As a huge bonus there is the whole strange world to explore, with great and varied scenery, and the back story of the creation of this world, which contains some deep philosophical questions. Did I mention the game was big? After 45 odd hours I think I am approaching the half way point, but probably less than that.

The mechanics work flawlessly and visually the game stunning. (for the G2 to work you must not be on the Beta Steam release). That said the VR game is now 5+ years old, so it is not exactly cutting edge by todayâ€™s standards but it has held up remarkably well. It does not stress my pretty middling VR system at all. I canâ€™t imagine playing all through the game, but you can easily abandon it to come back when you want to, playing it in suitable chunks. Voice acting and sound effects are spot on. 

If you enjoy VR for its ability to immerse you in new surroundings, and want some thoughtful puzzle to solve, this is a must have game, even with no discount as it is now pretty cheap full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992848097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2092, 'last_played': 1680840473}
review: Started a little slow but ended up really liking this game. If you are not a fan of puzzles this will not be for you. If you enjoy figuring out puzzles, you will enjoy this game. I also enjoyed the story of the game and how it unveiled itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198176606006', 'num_games_owned': 775, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1238, 'last_played': 1680995457}
review: Played the original first, then coming back after years to play the VR version is totally worth it. It truly brings a new sense to it thanks to VR !

author: {'steamid': '76561198022290252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2107, 'last_played': 1705581270}
review: If you like puzzles and scifi and you enjoy thinking about the trolley problem, then you absolutely 100% must play this game. It is morally obligatory. The breadth of ideas and small details will reward you endlessly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968861790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1675211978}
review: Cerebral puzzles are great, however, puzzles where you have to RUSH from one place to the next in VR with crappy controls are another entirely. If you can't win a puzzle because the controls suck, that means that the GAME SUCKS. At first, I thought it was me, but then I had 6 other people try a certain puzzle over and over again and they couldn't do it because of the controls. If the DEV takes out the puzzles where you have to rush and do this delicate balance between positions, its decent software. Otherwise, stop wasting my time. I could be saving patients.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970418298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1705690539}
review: Absolute waste of money. The VR engine implementation is abysmal and headache-inducing. Enjoyed playing the Talos Principle on PC and was looking forward to playing it on VR. However the flickering / shimmering is atrocious, the anti-aliasing is dreadful, and even after 2-3 hours of messing around with settings I couldn't get it into a playable state. On a Quest 2 but tried with Radeon 5700XT and nVidia RTX 4080, Oculus VR, wired link and Virtual Desktop, and the experience is exactly the same each time. Definitely a problem with the game itself. What a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025722495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1673720594}
review: There are points in this game where the controls are just too jank for VR, and I have Knuckles.  Once the timing becomes critical and you just cant highlight/grab that box in the one sec window your given, its game over.  This is why Valve play tested Alyx for months; you just cant mess up even one point in a linear game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198187118122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1595200860}
review: Some neat puzzles in this

author: {'steamid': '76561198158379873', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1340, 'last_played': 1703056150}
review:
One of the better puzzle games out there. Clean puzzles with no cheap puzzles at all, clear mechanics, good dialogue and story.

If you are not sure if you should get VR or standard version its pretty much the same so its up to you. The VR port works fine but it doesnt really add anything specific to VR so you wouldnt miss out too much playing the standard version. But if you have and like VR you could get this one you get the DLC for free. Either way the game is really really good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996829390', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1671243844}
review:
I absolutely love the Talos Principle, but as a VR title, this has not aged very well.

Controls are clunky and simplistic. Every interaction is simply point and click. One of the first puzzles involves a big beefy lever, and I was really disappointed when I tried to grab it and it just magically moved by itself.

Interacting with the MLS also feels pretty bad. The UI is text boxes that appear over the keyboard, and you have to just poke the reply you want and try to not accidently hit the wrong one.

There's also a jarring effect where if you try to reach your hand out of bounds like through the window in the peephole mission, you get teleported slightly backwards. I think that's unnecessary.

Similarly, ladders teleport you to the top, or the other side of the wall. It's unpleasant.

I think this version of the game would have been pretty killer in 2017, but today it's just unimpressive. It reads like a low-effort VR port.

I've had this on my wishlist since it was released and only now got around to getting a VR headset to give it a spin. I'm a little disappointed.

This isn't a bad game by any means. Talos is a *fantastic* game and if you're considering playing it, you will enjoy it. But the VR version doesn't stand up to the quality of VR games today.

If you've played any VR games from the last couple of years, I'd recommend you skip this game and play the regular version of Talos. If you've never played VR before, you will probably enjoy this a lot more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995651227', 'num_games_owned': 1230, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 3241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3099, 'last_played': 1669417787}
review:
This easily stands alongside Portal and Antichamber when it comes to fun FPS puzzle games with exploits derived from out of the box thinking, but adds a twist of heavy religious iconography and the deep introspection on the nature of consciousness, free will, and reality as a concept. While there may be a flatscreen PC version available, when you're playing in VR, the level of personal impact it adds cannot be overstated.

There is a ton of content as well. Aside from each of the individual puzzles, there are extra stars scattered about to collect, and even on top of that, there is a plethora of easter egg content, ranging from hidden rooms to statue puzzles, and even crossover cameos.
The only complaint I have is that several of the stars/eastereggs required movement that is almost impossible in VR, either needing to switch out of classic controls and use teleportation mode in order to have enough control over landing points to not be an exercise in futility. Alternatively, some easter eggs were outright removed entirely (no telescopes for viewing the aperture moon or lady liberty apparently) The VR version also has very limited guide support on steam. I ended up opening the guides that were on the page for the flatscreen version. The easteregg guide was particularly helpful, if only because I would have otherwise thought that content was part of an actual puzzle.
The other complaint is that I may have inadvertently cheesed a massive amount of content with an exploit involving the cubes that may only be possible in VR. Despite this, even the cheese methods required a fair amount of effort to pull off, so perhaps it was left in intentionally to offset the movement difficulties when compared to the flatscreen version. It still felt next-level cerebral regardless of whether it was the intended solution or not. (and sometimes breaking the puzzle is even more fun than solving it)

The difficulty of all the puzzles ramped up at a nearly perfect level. I would always feel like I had a general understanding of what needed to be done, but then be forced to revise my evaluation as I got deeper into each puzzle. The puzzle would clearly convey what pieces were needed, and then the task of finding out how to get the needed pieces to the location in question became the trick to solving the puzzle. The unorthodox applications of each mechanic would also have some basic puzzle designed to teach you about the potential use on future (sometimes even previously encountered) puzzles.

It wont be for everyone. I have a knack for these types of puzzles, and even for me, several of the puzzles were incredibly frustrating and finicky. There were one or two stars that I absolutely HAD to use the guide to be able to solve, as they were OBNOXIOUSLY obscure. A lot of the content that lets you know what exactly is going on is also conveyed through big walls of text, so if you're not big on reading, you're only getting about 50% of the context for everything.
That all said, the scenery is beautiful, index controllers are supported, the content is introspective and thought provoking, and steam has plenty of guides that cover practically everything the game has. If you can play in VR, and you have a graphics card that can handle the load, then it's one of the best VR games and/or puzzle games I've played, period.

review:
I played the Talos Principle first on flatscreen, but had to play through again as soon as I saw it out for VR. I really loved this game, and making it VR just added to the experiences I already loved.

The Game's puzzle platforming works well in VR. The focus on puzzles allows most people not to become motionsick, and the teleport movement didn't take away from the puzzling at all. The environments are still gorgeous, and I love just being present in the space.

If you have VR, and like puzzle adventures, this is a must play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198871833476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1372, 'last_played': 1665440678}
review:
I just finally finished the base game after months of playing and to sum it up succinctly I strongly recommend this. The controls are a little wonky with the Valve Index but it's not a big deal. Just use your left hand to pick up the sigils and you'll be fine.

I didn't know what to expect when I bought it. I kept seeing the title pop up in old threads where people recommended their favorite VR games. I had it on my wishlist and picked it up when it was on sale. Long story short I fell in love with this game and it is one of my all time favorites now.

I loved the combination of the puzzle complexity within the 3 ancient worlds; Roman, Egyptian, and medieval. Despite being hard at times the atmosphere was always super chill until you got to the very last level before you beat the game. The only level that required a time limit was the very last one. The music is great and appropriately themed for each of the three worlds. There are easter eggs everywhere if you look for them. The puzzles range from being pretty easy and able to be done in a few minutes to extremely difficult that may stump you for over an hour or longer.

Solving these puzzles using moveable components in a life-sized setting is something that in my opinion should only be experienced in VR and it works so well. You won't be able to get that same effect of feeling like you are there within the massive and complicated puzzle unless you're playing it in VR.

The lore is deep enough to be interesting but not overly complicated and it's certainly not half-assed like most games. It delves into AI, the past, and the future. It doesn't get as deep as SOMA but it's interesting enough. It's all a nice medley of concepts that merge together wonderfully and make for a game that I always looked forward to playing and I'd want to read everything I came across.

It's funny that the puzzles can seem so daunting at first but then when you solve them they seem easy in retrospect. I recommend not looking at any guides, videos, or walkthroughs and trying to solve the puzzles completely on your own. If you're stumped by one, move onto the next one, and come back to it tomorrow.

My favorite thing about the game other than the feeling of solving a puzzle was the nostalgic library assistant '90's computer terminals that you interact with on every level.

In conclusion, it's a must-play VR game if you are into puzzles, especially if you're at all interested in the future of AI and ancient cultures. I'd love to see these developers make more games like this. I honestly can't even comprehend how a team of people can make puzzles this complicated to solve. It kind of blows my mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044311169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 23, 'playtime_at_review': 3121, 'last_played': 1712088311}
review:
This is my favorite VR game so far. Though this is a port of a regular flatscreen game, the VR version is nearly perfect. You wouldn't assume it's any different from the regular version, but VR adds depth to small things that you wouldn't normally think about. You really feel like you're inside a virtual garden of Eden - visual glitches in the simulation happen to your entire field of vision, the different instruments have a "physical feel" to them because you handle them precisely using motion controllers, Elohim's voice really is coming from all around you.

It may not have the gigabytes of detailed assets of HL: Alyx, but it makes up for it with pure gameplay - there are more than 100 puzzles to figure out, and they are structured in a way where the difficulty scales very linearly. Certain concepts and tricks are introduced on earlier levels, which are then expanded upon for later levels. The environments are beautiful and pleasant to spend time in, the game doesn't rush you for anything and you are free to explore. There are plenty of hidden secrets and puzzles to discover. The soundtrack is excellent. If you are sick of cheap Quest2 Beat Saber clones definitely give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067347675', 'num_games_owned': 1398, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1760, 'last_played': 1660578876}
review:
The game translates well to VR for the most part, and it helps to give you a better perspective on things like the Lasers and where they can and can't go. It is of course more immersive as VR always will be, but there are some trade-offs as things can be a bit more clunky to interact with such as placing things on top of moving objects. It's also a bit less enjoyable reading off the computer screens but that's more a fault of current VR tech than anything else.

I would say if you enjoy puzzle games in VR this is an easy purchase, but regardless if you haven't played this or the original, I would recommend the original to anybody who even slightly enjoys puzzles. The story is great, the puzzles are amazing, the world is interesting and atmospheric, the secrets are very sneaky and difficult. There's pretty much nothing I can fault about the game - absolutely amazing. 

Below is my review for the original:

Easily the best puzzle game I have ever played, and it even has a fantastic story to go along with it. Numerous diverse and interesting puzzle mechanics that are used in creative and unique ways, alongside very interesting and difficult secrets that can have you searching for ages. Puzzles often require thinking multiple steps ahead to prepare things in advance to complete later sections, and rarely (if ever) is a solution immediately apparent without some thinking involved after the first few levels.

If you even SLIGHTLY enjoy puzzles then I couldn't recommend this game enough. A bargain at any price. Can't wait for the 2nd one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048904494', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1656196572}
review: Every human society in recorded history has games. We don't just solve problems out of necessity. We do it for fun. Even as adults. Leave a human being alone with a knotted rope and they will unravel it. Leave a human being alone with blocks and they will build something. Games are part of what makes us human. We see the world as a mystery, a puzzle, because we've always been a species of problem-solvers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116369032', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1139, 'last_played': 1653255364}
review:
This game has interesting puzzles (particularly in Road to Gehenna), some genuinely funny writing (again, mostly in Road to Gehenna), and potent philosophical themes and musings. Essentially, the game discusses the end of the world, immortality through memories, the nature of AI and consciousness, and what it all means. 

 All of this is wrapped up in a package of neat puzzles solved entirely in a 3D space from a first-person perspective, relying on interacting with the environment through perspective puzzles with lasers, basic topology-based puzzles with jammers, a time travel/parallel universe gimmick, and a bunch of other stuff. Unfortunately, most of the puzzles in the base game are mindlessly easy (coming from Stephen's Sausage Roll and The Witness, anyway) but Road to Gehenna provides some challenging and truly ingenious puzzles. Overall, the puzzle-solving is fun, and occasionally truly challenging (hence, rewarding).

So yeah, I would recommend this game to people who like waxing philosophical (like myself) and simple puzzles. The graphics and sound are pretty, and there is also some exploration with finding hidden/hard-to-reach stars, but it's not particularly interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977954030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1557614759}

havent beaten it just cause im not a puzzle guy- I have to be in a mood for it, but when I was, it was fun
the cmd / console portions where kinda boring since you just stand there in VR but they were ok for story telling

overall i would recommend if you like puzzles, and if not maybe get on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561197971466155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1653000429}
review: It's pretty nice looking for a port, and the controls are pretty good too. The puzzles are pretty simple, but they are engaging enough. Some of the levels seem extremely easy, even toward the end. The islands are nice to look at, walking around slowly and taking it in is pretty nice. The story did not do anything for me, and I stopped interacting with the weird computer terminals, audio logs, and QR codes, none of that seemed very interesting. Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance. For me, the puzzles, atmosphere, and level of polish are enough to make it a thumbs up though.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042823675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1711, 'last_played': 1671486411}
review:
Excellent jeu en VR. Comme c'est une adaptation d'un jeu plat, certaines mÃ©caniques peuvent paraÃ®tre bizarre au 1er abord. On a bien 2 mains, mais on ne peut attraper des objets que dans une seule Ã  la fois (sinon Ã§a aurait foutu en l'air les mÃ©caniques de rÃ©solution d'Ã©nigme)

Visuellement c'est trÃ¨s rÃ©ussi, mais il y a souvent un effet de flou un disgracieux en arriÃ¨re plan, mais pas toujours, Ã§a semble dÃ©pendre du type d'objets et textures qu'on trouve au loin. Il est possible que ce soit liÃ© au mode de compression d'image du quest2. Peut Ãªtre qu'il n'y a pas ce problÃ¨me avec les casques qui diffusent directement la 3d

Le jeu laisse beaucoup de possibilitÃ©s de choix dans les types de dÃ©placement

Bien content de ne pas avoir fait ce jeu en version plate avant, je n'aurais sans doute pas eu la motivation suffisante pour le refaire en vr sinon

Le dlc est inclus

author: {'steamid': '76561197985799605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1010, 'last_played': 1648487452}
review:
This may be a bit -stream of consciousness-, but well, now that i'm done crying my eyes out at the "true" ending, i feel i have to let the world know about this game. Late to the party, i know, and what can i say about this game that hasn't been said? Not much, i think.

Look, here's the deal: This isn't my -favourite- game, now. It's mechanically fairly simple, and the presentation isn't gonna blow you away. Nice sound, both VA and music, but yeah.

However, in terms of it's context? In terms of the themes, the meaning, the story behind the game? I believe in my very heart that while it's not the -best- game ever made, it IS the most -important- game to be released to date, on a philosophical level.

I don't want to sound pretentious, but if you are a being with any capacity for conscious thought beyond surface level, you absolutely owe it to yourself to play this. It may be humbling, or perhaps enlightening, depending on where you stand. The world needs more people who have had experiences like this.

From what i can tell, it's identical to the non-VR version in content, so if you're not sure, perhaps go for that one. I'm reviewing this one because i only play VR games, these days. (A sequel to this might be an exception to that rule. It's been announced, but who knows if there'll be a VR version of it.)

So.... yeah. Late to this party, but still, i feel i need to sing it the highest praises possible. Buy this. Or buy the non-VR version.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991593309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1609, 'last_played': 1642340516}
review:
Enjoyed this game a lot more than I expected to. If you enjoy the puzzle aspects of Portal you'll have  a great time. The mechanics of the puzzles are obviously different, but it's the same kind of thinking and enjoyment from solving them

The story is much more background, but it does a good job of setting the mood and feeling if you're reading through the texts.

The game is obviously a port for VR, so some things feel a little weird (inability to duck under objects, strange snapping when trying to set objects in certain places, and for index controls bizarrely a grabbing motion will both grab and jump and from what I can tell you can't change it)

However it's one of the VR games that I've actually spent a lot more time in than I would have thought. It's compelling, and despite some eccentricities the controls are very customizable and overall pleasant.

Very enjpyable. If you're in the mood for puzzles it's a must play

author: {'steamid': '76561197990882020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1640059096}
review:
I wish I could request a refund for this, but unfortunately I left it for a while before finally trying it out. There's regret.

TLDR; I loved the original Talos Principle, but I cannot recommend this version. Read below for details.

For folks using the Valve Index controllers, the controls make the game unplayable, or at best, hugely frustrating.
In the teleport movement modes, picking up an object and teleporting are mapped to the same control (squeezing the grip). So half the time when you pick something up, you also teleport. It also happens when you drop stuff, sometimes. Cue annoyingly avoidable deaths caused by teleporting into hazards instead of picking up or putting objects down.

Tapping the touchpad will also teleport you. If you turn off "click to move" it teleports you whenever you barely touch the touchpad. There's no way to turn off teleportation from the touchpad. To be clear - you can teleport using way too many controls. Gripping either controller, both A buttons, both touchpads, both analog sticks. The trigger is completely unused.

It's really difficult to move to locations very close to you using the teleport, since it's not point-and-move. It's more like lobbing a ball high in the air and hoping it lands in the right spot.

The above is slightly offset if you use "Classic" movement mode, where you just spontaneously jump when manipulating objects. But this can make many people nauseous, and there's not even a setting to change the snap-angle for rotation (no continuous rotation either).

Graphics settings are... Glitchy. Setting GPU speed to "Ultra" and "Medium" work, but "High" and "Low" cause huge glitches (everything monochrome purple, or vanishing textures, etc). Mixed Reality settings can crash your headset entirely (even on a Windows MR headset).

There's individual finger tracking... But it doesn't actually [i]do[/i] anything.

The list goes on...

author: {'steamid': '76561198027419494', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1637626124}
review:
The Talos Principle is a puzzle game with a story that asks philosophical questions about being human, life, death and eternal life.

You will wake up in a garden and hear the words of Elohim, god-like creature claiming to have created you, guiding you one of his children to a temple and telling you to pass different kind of tests.

You will learn that you should be collecting Sigils to progress. Each of these is at the end of a spatial puzzle. Each of the puzzles is taking place in a closed area that can often feel like a labyrinth. You will have to deal with forcefields, sentinels (some explode when you walk closer to them), laser guns, closed door etc. For that you can use one or more tools you will get on your journey. For example, one tool will allow you to redirect laser beams, other will disable a forcefield or stop a sentinel in its track. There is also a cube that you can use in various ways (climb, or use to put pressure on something) and a fan that allows you to get to difficult to access places for example. One of the weirdest tools is a recording device (when you need two people to solve the puzzle).

The Sigils you will be collecting have a form of a tetrimino and are used to unlock doors. You will unlock a way to other very distinct worlds. In each world there is a hub from which there are doors leading to other parts of that one world. There you have the individual puzzles rewarding you with the Sigils. The Sigils have different colors and the difficulty of the puzzles is also reflected in that. You will start with collecting Green and Yellow Sigils mostly and these puzzles are quite easy. The green ones are good introductory puzzles, yellow ones are about testing what you learned from the green ones. In the later stages of the game all you will be collecting are red tetriminos and it is where it starts to get complicated. While exploring the worlds and solving puzzles you might come across golden stars. Those you can also collect and will take you through a hidden door to other puzzles. In order to get a golden star you will have to think outside of the individual puzzles, you will often need tools from different puzzles. There are different ways how to solve these and are very fun. Actually sometimes you won't even see the star itself, you will just encounter something that's not supposed to be there and after you get there you will discover a star. All the puzzles are very satisfying to solve and the star challenges were really brilliant and often breathtaking. The names of the puzzles are something to pay attention to, especially if you get stuck because they will give you a hint.

One of the great things is also the fact that you don't need to do any of the puzzles in a certain order but you do need to collect specific tetriminos and certain amount of stars in order to open doors. It gives you freedom and also won't frustrate you if you get stuck. You can just go do different puzzles and come back (to realize how simple the solution was). All the puzzles are very well designed and while some need you to stack objects in a certain way you will mostly be thinking about how to effectively use the tools at your disposal since you've got a limited amount which is lower than the number of obstacles.

While exploring you will encounter QR messages from other children, audio logs, and (beeping) terminals. This is where the story part of the game takes places. When you hear a beeping sound and go closer you will discover a terminal on which you can read messages and articles from a corrupted archive and this way you will learn that something went terribly wrong. You will start asking yourself questions and later you will start a conversation with conscious artificial intelligence. It is here where most of the philosophical questions will be asked. This being will start questioning you and you will have to think hard how to answer. Your point of view will then be questioned and it is up to you whether you change your mind or not. The thing is, you are a robot while you think you are a human being, but are you?

You will start to think about mythology, eternal life, God, technology and (trans)humanity. Maybe you'll start pondering about your own future and the future of today's society. You will always be given a lot of time to ponder about all these questions and doing puzzles in the meantime. When you hear the next beep, you will most probably be ready for next encounter.

The conscious in the computer system will start making you doubt your creator - Elohim. You will most probably start questioning Elohim (hopefully because than the game will end prematurely) and start wondering what's at the top of the Tower which he forbid you to visit and will remind you of it whenever you start climbing up. If you decide to climb the tower you will learn even more and will still be able to decide what the outcome of the game will be.

I'm not entirely sure how to write about all that is going on in the game, I'm not that good of a writer. The experience is very unique and personal. The story is very deep, poses very important questions and everything is very well written. In all that there is even room for humor.

Even though I wanted to end the review here, I should also comment on graphics and sound. The game is very beautiful. The environments are large and I spent hours just walking around enjoying the view, the atmospherical effects and even tried to reach different places to see the environment from different point of views. This sometimes resulted in me stumbling upon a golden star. I had no problems with performance in VR and enjoyed a crystal clear and sharp textures all the time no matter how fast I moved or how close I was a wall. I was actually surprised how well the game looks on Rift because many games don't that great compared to Index. I would have never guessed this game is from 2014. Music and sound is excellent. Music is a delight and I'd just stand on the beach, watch the setting sun and listen to the music. The little voice acting there is, is impeccable - in terms of it makes you feel emotions and not many games I played achieved that.

Verdict:
I bought this game for the puzzles but very soon realized that it is not about the puzzles. While the game can be played just as a puzzle game, and very good one, you will miss a lot if you ignore the story. The story is philosophical, thought-provoking, well written. The game has a very good learning curve, is also well structured and offers even more challenging puzzles to hardcore players. The game environments are distinct, beautiful, breathtaking and simply serene. The music is soothing for the soul. In overall it is a perfect game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041030074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1637580022}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960478145', 'num_games_owned': 2351, 'num_reviews': 616, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1636290935}
review:
I give up trying to fix this. Looks like it doesn't want to get fixed.

The first time I booted it up, it was pretty neat, actually. Well, the default control configuration had gripping & teleporting on the same input, but that's nothing that can't be fixed with Steam's capabilities.

Along came an update which screwed up controls royally. After that update, merely touching the sticks caused a teleport. Bad idea. Very bad idea.

So I've spent hours upon hours trying to fix that. Did you know that different 3D rendering APIs can affect input? Neither did I! Depending on the API, single-finger tracking works or doesn't. Either way, I wasn't able to get this game to control like it doesn't have a hangover.

Today, I had fresh motivation to take it upon me to tame this stubborn ass. Except it now doesn't even render in my Index. Tried to troubleshoot my system, tried a couple of other VR games, tried redownloading after deleting the local settinfs file, it's SOL all right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025337386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1634679218}
review: I like this port. While VR may not add much to the actual gameplay as you can only carry one item at once, the visuals are pretty and it's very handy to freely position each item with your actual hands. If you have a VR headset I'd say that you should go for this version over the flat version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198225696528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1634693190}
review: This game feels like it was made for VR. I had been considering playing it for years, but I'm glad I waited for the VR version. The puzzles are fun to solve for the first time in this immersive environment. My only complaint is that the default controls could be slightly better, I occasionally jump when trying to grab things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018803041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 4206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4206, 'last_played': 1632585146}
review: Bon, il est temps de donner son avis sur "The Talos Principle VR" aprÃ¨s 70 heures de jeu. Cet avis est simple : il s'agit du meilleur jeu de rÃ©alitÃ© virtuelle auquel j'ai jouÃ© jusqu'Ã  prÃ©sent et pourtant, les puzzle games ont le mÃªme effet rÃ©pulsif sur moi qu'une messe dans une mosquÃ©e pour Eric Zemmour. Seulement, voilÃ  : la VR se prÃªte Ã  merveille au gameplay et Ã  la dynamique de jeu de "The Talos Principle", ainsi qu'Ã  ses ambiances envoÃ»tantes prenant place dans l'univers grÃ©co-romain, en Egypte antique ou dans le Moyen Ã‚ge chrÃ©tien de l'Europe (les fÃ©rus mÃ©lancoliques d'histoire et de vieilles ruines Ã©mouvantes comme moi vont adorer - non, je ne parle pas de la chanteuse Madonna, lÃ ) ; lesdites ambiances deviennent immersives comme pas possible une fois que l'on a le casque sur la tÃªte. De plus, les Ã©nigmes - qui consistent Ã  rÃ©cupÃ©rer des objets gÃ©omÃ©triques faisant penser Ã  celles de "Tetris" (j'ai oubliÃ© le nom qu'on leur donne dans le jeu) - sont trÃ¨s stimulantes intellectuellement. Quand l'esprit est plongÃ© dans les intenses rÃ©flexions nÃ©cessaires pour les trouver, il n'arrive plus Ã  penser Ã  autre chose, mÃªme Ã  l'obligation de se laver pour garder sa dignitÃ© d'Ãªtre humain. Un bÃ©mol, toutefois : la quÃªte des Ã©toiles (l'autre artefact Ã  collecter) est beaucoup plus costaude, un peu trop mÃªme, et j'avoue ne pas avoir mis la main sur la totalitÃ© d'entre elles, ce qui m'a empÃªchÃ© de dÃ©couvrir la troisiÃ¨me fin (oui, il y a trois fins diffÃ©rentes en tout). Concernant le DLC "Road to Gehenna", je n'en dirai malheureusement pas du bien : il reprend le mÃªme principe (rÃ©cupÃ©rer nos figures gÃ©omÃ©triques, donc), les mÃªmes environnements (pourquoi ne pas en avoir crÃ©Ã© au moins un nouveau, comme la Chine de Confucius ou les goulags de Staline ?) mais pousse les Ã©nigmes jusqu'Ã  un niveau de complexitÃ© parfaitement inouÃ¯e. Les concepteurs n'auraient pas du oublier qu'un jeu vidÃ©o est d'abord une rÃ©crÃ©ation mentale, pas une torture cÃ©rÃ©brale. Bref, j'ai dÃ©cidÃ© de ne pas terminer ce DLC. Dommage : cette idÃ©e d'un groupe d'IA prisonniÃ¨res d'un monde virtuel trop beau pour Ãªtre honnÃªte Ã©tait fort sÃ©duisante.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972577018', 'num_games_owned': 1449, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1631542617}
review: This looks beautiful and the puzzle mechanics should suit VR really well. Unfortunately, the game requires a lot of (virtual) moving around, and wasn't comfortable to play in anything more than short bursts. I might finish it on a flat screen instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028931761', 'num_games_owned': 1638, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1634436718}
review:
The Talos Principle is an excellent puzzle game, steeped heavily in philosophy and religion. This kind of experience is what VR should be used for. Putting yourself directly in makes all the themes hit even harder, and the visuals are beautiful.
I am quite biased, but seriously A7 is so beautiful it made me look up if there is any places like it in real life so I could hike there.

Wonderful game if you are prepared to stop and soak in the themes, and if you are like me and have already beaten this game in flat mode it's still worth having this more personal experience a second time around.

Worth full price if you have never played the game before, if you already own it in flat then I'd still recomend picking it up again once it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105109732', 'num_games_owned': 1008, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1550705174}
review:
A full puzzle game in VR. 
The old ruins and Egyptian style architecture are majestic and fearsome.
Puzzle is fun.

I know as of 2021 there still are many full game in VR. This is one. If you enjoy puzzle game you would love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982726718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1558, 'last_played': 1646521579}
review:
Overall I liked this game. There was some difficulty with using the Valve Index controllers as others have mentioned but I thought the game was interesting enough to plow through some of those frustrating parts where the controller configuration made it more difficult than it ought to have been. Most of the time that wasn't a problem. I've played through the game once and plan on playing through it again to see what the different endings are. 

I thought it was good to see a game which included philosophical subjects. Although I was disappointed with some of the options that were given when interfacing with the computer that asks you the questions as I think there are often better answers than what was listed. I do realize though that it is a video game so they can't list everything. One of the things I thought incoherent was the games perspective is assuming philosophical naturalism. The mind doesn't even make sense in that kind of world. Would the virtual world exist if minds weren't there to create it in the first place? How would one get the mind from things that have no mind? Or math, reason, language, etc. Those things, while they have connections to the physical world, they are not subject to it. If the virtual world would not exist without human beings creating it, would not something similar apply to the universe?

author: {'steamid': '76561198045661062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1620903389}
review:
The Talos Principle is a brilliant puzzle game. I'm not too comfortable with moving in VR and got quite a bit of motion sickness from it (despite it having all the typical comfort features). Sadly it's not possible to switch between regular and VR gameplay, making it hard to for me to play much in one session. Controlling is a bit fiddle in VR. Got the PS4 version instead now, which is much more to my liking.

VR version not really recommended, but the regular game is brilliant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999461406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1627490052}
review: Like the other reviewers mention the Index controls on this game are just terrible. Why did they not offer a config option to change the grab action from grips to some other button I have no idea. Luckily I also own some Vive wands so I am using those to play it. This game was definitely designed to be played in non VR. It is still quite fun in VR but everything will be slightly harder to do in VR than non VR. That said I do still enjoy it in VR, the presence of being inside the world gives the game a new feeling. Overall I would recommend the game but if you have Index controllers be warned. They will not be an issue during the early puzzles but you will get frustrated at later points when you try and drop an object and pick it up on accident with the index sensitive grip controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1627854453}
review:
As the years pass, maybe some of us including myself forget the glory of old gems. Like The Talos Principle in VR.

Recently I upgraded to a RTX 3090 and i9 10900K from a GTX 1080 and i7 7700K, and even if Talos Principle VR did work fine before, for the first time I could select Ultra settings for all graphics and res 200% - and get 90 fps.

Admitted, with those settings I'm not getting solid 90 fps - in extremely large locations I do go below 90 fps, but most places are 90 fps.

I was amazed with how awesome the graphics look - actually just played some DeMagnete, and the contrast coming to Talos VR was really great, like mind-blowingly great. Talos VR has close to Alyx graphics, and I don't state that lightly. Of course Alyx wins, but using Ultra settings in Talos VR the dynamic lights and shadows are fantastic. I guess texture quality isn't quite similar to Alyx, but Croteam adds a layer of additional details when you get close to textures - it looks amazing.

Your hands look great too - not better than Alyx with the gravity gloves, but apart from Alyx I'm not sure I can recall a game with much better VR hands :-)

In short - if you have just upgraded to a fast gpu, or if you have never tried Talos VR, this may be the best puzzle game you can get. Or close!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999920602', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 624, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1573484133}
review: I never played the original game, but the VR version has made me want to try it out. For a VR game, it's pretty decent and it has everything I need; lots of graphics options, and the ability to move with teleport. Controls weren't perfect but they're ok. It's a fairly straightforward set of puzzles and translates well to VR. It's pretty, and has decent sound effects. Only get it on sale though; â‚¬35 is way too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995587898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1615592758}
review:
Played on Valve Index

Wow. This game has really been amazing so far but this port to VR is simply revolting. Walking, picking up items, entering the gate-puzzles, interacting with ladders, all of it takes twice as long in VR than if you were to just play the original version of the game. This just feels a like a cash-grab with none of the attention to detail put into the original. This is not meant to be a fun experience, just to cash in on VR-Gimmicks.

Here is a solid piece of evidence for how bad the Port is based on the Steam achievements Global stats:
54% of players actually beat the first 1/4 of the standard game (The Land of Death Achievement)
9% of players actually beat the first 1/4 of the VR game (The Land of Death Achievement)
^^There is a reason that only 1/6 of the player base reaches this checkpoint in the the VR edition. Its because they get frustrated with the port and quit.

This is probably the best puzzle game I've played since Portal 2, but do yourself a favor and pick up the standard edition if you want to have a good time with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040922643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1624173578}
review:
DO. NOT. BUY. THIS. GAME. 

This game is absolutely beautiful!  I love the puzzles and the little bits of story I've uncovered are fascinating!  

A bug in the game prevents moving beyond the first area.  You reach an elevator, push the button and it just *buzzes* but never moves the elevator. 

I've found multiple forums talking about it (including the community board here on steam).  Croteam has known about it and apparently not bothered to fix it since 2019.  The advice I've found is to just try pushing the button from different angles until it registers. I've tried pretty much every angle, depth of push, and quickness of push imaginable with zero luck.  I emailed them for support 10 days ago with no response at all.  Steam refuses to even consider a refund because I've played for more than two hours (most of that time spent backtracking thinking I must have missed something to unlock the elevator and they immediately close every ticket I send them asking them to communicate with me about WHY I'm asking for a refund. 

Do. Not. Buy. This. Game.
At least, not for VR.  
If you want to play it, look at the standard PC version instead (the two versions, VR and flatscreen are sold as completely separate products unlike almost every single other VR/flatscreen game available on Steam)

author: {'steamid': '76561198201386637', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1622790198}
review:
I was going to try this out as a fun VR experience as I really wanted something puzzle-like to just wander around in VR to get a handle of it. I have decided playing this game on VR as my first playthru would be a bad idea with how difficult it is JUST to get the game to look right. The flashing green problem is a common visual glitch on the VR edition, and while there are fixes for it, and I was able to fix it, I came upon new and more frustrating graphical glitches that have existed since this games VR release. Everything has this red and brown muted tinge to it. And there are solutions to this problem that work for people. I have tried these solutions and the problems persist for me. I cannot fix it. Graphics are not everything but when you're in a VR helmet and you want to get immersed into something and youre very aware of how the game doesn't look as its supposed to..it kind of ruins the fun.

I will be playing this on my PS4 instead. A real shame. I do not recommend this game unless they finally address these graphical problems.

review: I have not played the regular version but I thoroughly enjoyed the VR version.  Great story, very well done VR implementation that doesnâ€™t feel like a port, decent graphics, and fun puzzles. The puzzles range from easy to a few head scratchers but I was never stuck too long or frustrated. I happily spent 25 hours + in VR. I felt very slight discomfort if I cranked the movement speed to max and even then it was playable. At the default setting I had no issues.

This is ridiculous. A blatant cash grab. The developers copy pasted the original game, and added VR support. Almost no effort required.
What if you wanted to try this game without VR? You would have to pay for the same game AGAIN to get the original game. The developers should have just added VR support to the original game.

review: One of the best puzzle games for VR! Very clever and challenging puzzles, great atmosphere, beautiful meditative landscapes and relaxing sound, deep, thought provoking philosophical context. Often found myself just wandering around, enjoying nature, waterfalls, listening birds, viewing murals and statues, swimming and enjoying sunshine, especially in all this lockdown situation. Must play !!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198384321457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1639872180}
review:
Great port in nearly every regard, but there is no jump button on the Rift S. Forums say that it works in an older version, but I have no idea how to downdate.

EDIT: a lot of the forums say to "downdate" or something to an older version, but I couldn't figuire out how.

Instead, they say to launch it thru oculus instead of SteamVR

not sure where I found this, but here's the fix I used: type [+vrapi Oculus] into the launch properties, minus the brackets.

it enables jumping with either of the upper buttons on the Rift S remotes. Note it does remove pausing, but that's not a terrible issue as you can pause with the escape button on the keyboard, and the port comes with a full "2D" GUI.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968241185', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1709226483}
review: The best VR remasters I've ever played. the graphics are stunning, and the game is well optimized, with a 1080 Ti and a generic ryzen I was able to play on all ultra settings on 125% res on a tethered Quest 2 on more or lress 90 FPS. The art, the music, and the game are all stunning, and I can't wait to get my full fix out of this game that I enjoyed so much on the pancake version. I'll be sure to play Road to Gehenna, also: you forget the more medium to hard puzzles after a few years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151342049', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1618867114}
review:
I strongly recommend this game if you ever were into puzzle games, they are so much better in VR!

The cool thing about this game is that even if you're stuck you just leave the puzzle and go on and on the next day you always smash it. Very satisfying.

The game has three endings, however one is boring and one is reachable only for (what I think) hardcore players since it's extremely hard without passtroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961017729', 'num_games_owned': 3005, 'num_reviews': 3428, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1709519112}
review:
[b]The Talos Principle VR is not a good VR game.[/b] It's another well functioning, but standard cookie cutter VR addon to a game that is already long and boring. I mean, it's no Portal. It certainly doesn't come close to having that games personality, but it's on the same wavelength. I like the aesthetic, and I'm generally hip to the concept. The big draw to The Talos Principle is the philosophical story, and the mystery and all that.

To earn that you have to do endless amounts of these boring puzzles that are all kinda similar to each other. [i]Does anyone else get a weird cellphone game progression type vibe with these puzzles?[/i] Still, you might like that, and the game is very peaceful (albeit also boring), which is a positive for VR generally, but it would be a waste of time to subject yourself to this whole game on an HMD. I got through a couple worlds, but then proceeded to just read the wikia and scroll paste a few youtube playthroughs.

Ideally you'd want to play alot of this on your monitor, but surprise! You have to buy the original version for that! It's just like Skyrim or all the other Croteam games. They're reselling the whole game again with the VR addon packaged. Both titles are 40 dollars. I'm not saying they can't sell the VR game for the same price as the other one, or have to package the port as a DLC instead. This would be fine if you could play the VR version on a monitor, but if you don't have the original game, you can't, and if you do, you still have to install both games and futz with the save files! There's a chance I'm wrong, or that maybe (with mods or something) you can play the game in 2d mode without buying the original package, if so, disregard. Still, Croteam and Bethesda price gouged on their VR ports like mad, and these are games that haven't been updated in years. [spoiler] I think the whole  game world is a computer simulation, haha spoiled it, but doesn't really seem that groundbreaking anyway when your inside your own VR system, eh.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041148954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1615774883}
review: The original game is great; the VR version is not, at least not on the Valve Index that it claims to support. Controls are very janky. Even after disabling the control that causes you to teleport when you grip the controller, which I can only assume was a mistake because nobody has ever wanted that behavior, it's still a huge pain to actually teleport where you want. I will regularly have the teleport circle in the right place, let go of the button to teleport, and jump to a completely different location. I don't know why this would be Index-specific, but people with other headsets seem to be happy so you might be ok with those. And as far as I can tell there is no way to rotate the teleport circle, which is a pretty bad omission, so get ready to constantly teleport and then rotate, over and over. Ultimately the game just doesn't adapt well to VR, too much of the game is moving around instead of interacting with the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022415153', 'num_games_owned': 969, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 1521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1521, 'last_played': 1613857606}
review: I so wish I could give a neutral review. It's good, but it's ultimately frustrating. The Talos Principle was not made for VR, Croteam did a good job porting it, but the fine placement of items in levels, as well as just the controls in general make it a frustrating experience for me.  The first 2 worlds are enjoyable though, but it just drags on too long to be an enjoyable VR experience for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198962463732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7078, 'last_played': 1622324824}
review: Excellent, atmospheric VR (Valve Index) puzzle game that has transferred well from the "pancake" version. Rendering of individual game worlds works well and each has a distinctive "look & feel"..... VR gameplay is functional, though object gripping & then dropping required strict controller accuracy (especially in action / mine / machine gun related sequences). Overall brilliant entertainment ...... now must go back to the Talos Garden and sort out that Serpent for those last few Achievements ....

author: {'steamid': '76561197970337659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1657408970}
review:
Endless Hours of puzzles. 
This is a great thinking puzzle game, the backdrop and concept is awesome. Just when I thought I had it complete and opened the first door to the elevator, and came out. It dawned on me that I had only just begun. This game has countless hours. The idea is collect tetris like pieces to open up other areas and unlock objects that will spawn in the puzzles. You can free room anywhere and go back to areas that you could not complete due to you not having the unlocked item.

The graphics are ok, I have no issues running this game on ultra with highest res but textures can still look a little  low res at times. Other than that I would highly recommend it if your big into puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979928405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 2058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1315, 'last_played': 1612496600}
review:
AWESOME AND WILD IN VR!! 
The original was an amazing and fun game but in VR it takes it to a whole new level. CroTeam did an excellent job with the port to VR with the exception of grabbing and placement although that could be my crap Oculus Rift-S headset. (I review that pos headset elsewhere so no sense rehashing here)
Puzzles are just as much fun as they were in pancake game. The world looks amazing and really captures that sense of what the heck happened to everyone. 
If you want another fun VR game get their Serious Sam VR one. Its just runnning around blasting stuff but omg the worlds look so amazing.! 

Awesome Job CroTeam!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043434029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2178, 'last_played': 1611674677}
review:
While the VR could use some quality of life improvements (a height adjust setting would be appreciated for Oculus API users), I was blown away by this game. A lot of people compare it to Portal, but I would actually say it more closely resembles The Witness, if The Witness actually had a story and a purpose behind all the philosophy it throws at you. The core puzzles aren't as difficult as in The Witness, though the secret stars are there if you want an elevated challenge. You don't need the stars for the "good" ending, you just need them for an alternate ending.

This game is difficult to sell without spoilers, so I'll just say it's a first-person puzzle-based self-actualization simulator. And if that sounds even a little bit interesting to you, this game is for you.

review: Loved the game. The puzzle solving and controls for the HTC Vive were perfect and then I got a Valve Index. Now I'm constantly fighting with the controls to do what I want. I keep teleporting when I want to grab the item in front of me. Not sure why they made the grip controls have two completely different behaviours, but the game has become too frustrating to play. I don't want to go back to using my Vive controllers just for this game so I'll likely just stop playing it.
