author: {'steamid': '76561198883538639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1398, 'last_played': 1577906317}
review:
Played on Index:

Bought it because of the VR version. And as a puzzle game it has a interesting story to tell. 

Positives: It has a story! The graphics and sound are fine. Control is o.k. apart from a few levels where you need have very precise (almost pixel perfect) placement/timing. And in VR that is sometimes a challenge

Regarding the level of the puzzles I did need a guide to get past a few of the puzzles.

Negatives: The end felt somewhat stretched.

Verdict: Good game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198880904124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11110, 'last_played': 1581273095}
review: This has been our favorite VR game so far.  It was relaxing to play, a great story with awesome views.  Can't recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028605194', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1302, 'last_played': 1598358198}
review:
This game is absolutely outstanding. The desktop version of this game was already amazing, but experiencing it in VR was something else. The game looks good - nothing incredible though - and the puzzles are still challenging and satisfying to go through.

This easily makes it to my "Must-buy" list of VR games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043175246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1369, 'last_played': 1591224557}
review: If you like puzzle games you will love this game. If you have VR then get this version. I already owned this game far before it came out for VR and I bought it again, its worth it. It takes an already amazing game and fully immerses you in its beautiful world. The music is absolutely gorgeous and the story that unfolds while you play will keep you wanting more. One of my favorite games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074922533', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1602542412}
review:
Upfront I'm going to say: if you've played the original game to 100% completion, this is not worth full price. The VR elements are a major improvement over the original interactive controls but do not augment the gameplay in a meaningful way. However if you have not, this is a good excuse it again, with the added suffering of collecting all the stars by not just thinking outside of the box, but becoming the box itself. 

Anyway, with that out of the way I'll review this from a fresh faced never played the pancake version before perspective. The Talos Principle is not necessarily a bastion of brand new ideas or a roadmark in the progression of the gaming industry, but is instead a culmination and even perfection of already existing functionality and mechanics. Despite not being something completely new or inventive, this is an incredibly memorable experience that will leave you thinking long after you finish the game. 

Starting with the VR implementation, quite frankly it's fantastic. The range of configuration options is extreme and even a little overwhelming so definitely take some time to dial it all in for the best experience. The texture quality is exceptional, and you'll notice this especially on higher settings as your framerate absolutely tanks. I'm running a 2080 Ti and it was working out like a procrastinator two weeks before a marathon. Interactivity is fluid and intuitive, especially with the Index controllers; however using the computer terminals could become a bit of a chore and I'm sure there's a better implementation for such a large part of the game. As someone with fairly strong VR legs (I do my virtual squats), I can't vouch too reliably for motion sickness induction, though I can safely say it's not great, but not [i] horrible /[i].

I'll not be covering the main game elements as they're already reviewed to death on the pancake version of the game, so for a look into the actual gameloop quality head over there. All I'll say is, the game is an absolute masterpiece and a serious treat.

Now the hard question: worth Â£30? If you've never played it before, absolutely without a doubt. If you've completed it normally with no extra content, maybe wait for Â£20 or so (or whatever you local currency equivalent is). If you've already played it 100%, then only if you're really bored, have too much money, or just really really want to see it in VR. And to be fair, it's absolutely beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993292466', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1600371908}
review: Excellent sci-fi philosophy story that stimulates your mind as much as the puzzles do. Really fun problem solving. VR doesn't really add to the gameplay but it adds to the story in a meta way. Really excellent puzzle game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050914695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1619223867}
review:
Colors are super bad when you start up the game, it would not be playable like this. I spent time searching for a fix, but none worked. I was just about to return the game when I gave it a last chance and started a real level, the issue disappears. In the forum, one can see that this bug has been there for months. The game studio seems to be indifferent, thus I expect this to be a low-quality game.

I wish VR games would be more polished, however VR immersion makes up for a lot and I actually got quite a lot of enjoyable playtime out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999675395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1639759724}
review:
Seemingly a quite simple VR-ification of a game, but I quite enjoy running around looking at the wondrous environments and feeling immersed in the riddles. Thumbs up!
(Played on Oculus Quest via Virtual Desktop)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970560479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1533, 'last_played': 1600608191}
review:
Talos Principle is an incredible puzzle game.

The VR port is breathtakingly beautiful, so much that it's fun to just wander around and enjoy the environment.

Unfortunately the VR controls are quite frustrating. Some puzzles require precise placement of objects (or of yourself!), which is difficult to do with teleport, often with a high cost of needing to restart / redo large chunks of a puzzle because the teleport didn't land in the right place. "Grab" for grab object and "tight grab" for teleport is insane: here comes a bomb, better not drop this thing I'm holding, oh wait I accidentally jumped directly into the bomb. Hmm. Grab really needs to be an on/off button anyway, not a touch sensor. It's too easy to drop something accidentally, or NOT drop something when trying to place it exactly. I toyed with all available controls options and couldn't find settings that felt easy to use.

Overall the [i]environment[i] works incredibly well in VR, but the controls do not. I'd rather play the non-vr version using mouse/keyboard and Vorpx for VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006914667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1597660962}
review:
At first I bought this for my girlfriend on her account then I almost had the game beat,  I will have to start over on my account.  This game is a lot of fun another reason bought it for VR. 
There are many levels, and this is not just a puzzle game there is also a somewhat of a story to play in between the levels.
If you like puzzles this is a must VR makes it feel like your more there,  I have had friends come over and play it in VR and they love it. 
I would rate this 4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197973505525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1513, 'last_played': 1681092644}
review: Interesting complicated puzzle based game with an interesting dark story interwoven into it. The VR version is amazing, the visuals were beautiful, although it is a must to turn on the smooth movement setting which could cause some nausea but is required for some puzzles. The story blew me away and made me really think what it is to be human while enjoying the interplay of evolution, religion, and technology. This game is underappreciated.

review:

PrzemierzajÄ…c ogrÃ³d rozwiÄ…zujemy zagadki w celu zebrania tzw. sigili, ktÃ³re wyglÄ…dajÄ… po prostu jak zwykÅ‚e klocki z klasycznego "Tetrisa". Po zebraniu odpowiedniej iloÅ›ci, moÅ¼emy przy ich pomocy odblokowaÄ‡ bramy prowadzÄ…ce w rÃ³Å¼ne inne zakÄ…tki Å›wiata, jednak warunek jest jeden - nie wolno nam wejÅ›Ä‡ do wieÅ¼y znajdujÄ…cej siÄ™ pomiÄ™dzy ogrodami. W trakcie podrÃ³Å¼y napotykamy na tajemnicze terminale, pliki oraz dziwne wiadomoÅ›ci ktÃ³re wprowadzajÄ… gracza w konsternacjÄ™.

The Talos Principle VR to klasyczna wersja Talosa przeportowana na wirtualnÄ… rzeczywistoÅ›Ä‡. Mam obie wersje i pomimo tego, Å¼e sÄ… fabularnie i zagadkowo takie same to tak naprawdÄ™ robiÄ…c przejÅ›cie z kompa na VR'a trzeba siÄ™ tej gry uczyÄ‡ od samego poczÄ…tku. Nie chodzi tutaj o inny typ sterowania - nie da siÄ™ tego w peÅ‚ni wyjaÅ›niÄ‡ sÅ‚owami - co innego jest patrzeÄ‡ na monitor i podziwiaÄ‡ grafikÄ™ lub detale, a zupeÅ‚nie inne jest doÅ›wiadczenie kiedy caÅ‚y umysÅ‚ przenosi siÄ™ do tego Å›wiata gry. WÅ‚aÅ›nie ta imersja VR'a sprawia, Å¼e pomiÄ™dzy tymi grami jest wielka przepaÅ›Ä‡ pod wzglÄ™dem emocji jakich doÅ›wiadcza gracz. 

Interakcja z przedmiotami jest podobnie jak w klasycznej wersji ograniczona wyÅ‚Ä…cznie do przedmiotÃ³w z ktÃ³rych musimy skorzystaÄ‡ by popchnÄ…Ä‡ fabuÅ‚Ä™ do przodu. Standardowo, mamy 3 opcje poruszania siÄ™ i tryb komfort dla osÃ³b wraÅ¼liwych - osobiÅ›cie polecam chociaÅ¼ sprÃ³bowaÄ‡ to wyÅ‚Ä…czyÄ‡ bo Å›wietne uczucie jest kiedy wskakuje siÄ™ na trampolinÄ™ lub wentylator. 

Nie brakuje tutaj rÃ³wnieÅ¼ - a jakÅ¼e - bugÃ³w. PÃ³ki co udaÅ‚o mi siÄ™ znaleÅºÄ‡ dziwnego buga, ktÃ³ry wystÄ™puje w momencie prÃ³by wskakiwania na obiekty (w grze, nie w realu). Kiedy odpowiednio wyceluje siÄ™ kontrolerem i bÄ™dzie skakaÄ‡ przy murku to w pewnym momencie zostaniemy.........ciÄ™Å¼ko to nazwaÄ‡ "wystrzeleniem".................. po prostu wyje**** z prÄ™dkoÅ›ciÄ… 2,5 macha w powietrze, gdzie moÅ¼emy na 2 sekundy zobaczyÄ‡ caÅ‚Ä… mapÄ™ z gÃ³ry, po czym uderzamy gÅ‚owÄ… w "sufit" tego Å›wiata i spadamy pionowo jak po wielkiej linijce dokÅ‚adnie w ten sam punkt z ktÃ³rego wystartowaliÅ›my. Przy kilku prÃ³bach moÅ¼na przebiÄ‡ siÄ™ przez ten "sufit" nad ktÃ³rym prawo grawitacji juÅ¼ nie obowiÄ…zuje co jest jednoznaczne z brakiem moÅ¼liwoÅ›ci powrotu na mapÄ™, a kaÅ¼dy skok powoduje unoszenie nas coraz wyÅ¼ej i wyÅ¼ej aÅ¼ w koÅ„cu (nie, nie spotkamy Elohima) lÄ…dujemy w limbo. Ot taki sobie bug.

Innym bugiem jaki znalazÅ‚em to brak moÅ¼liwoÅ›ci zdobycia jednej z gwiazdek, poniewaÅ¼ nie ma FIZYCZNEJ moÅ¼liwoÅ›ci aby po zrobieniu maÅ‚ej wieÅ¼yczki z kostek ktÃ³ra unosi siÄ™ na gÅ‚owie miny, wskoczyÄ‡ na te kostki. W klasycznej wersji nie ma tego problemu, ale na VR'ze spÄ™dzajÄ…c 30 minut na tym stosujÄ…c wszelkie moÅ¼liwe sposoby Å‚Ä…cznie z podchodzeniem w pokoju, gra nie pozwala zrobiÄ‡ markera do skoku na tÄ™ wieÅ¼Ä™, tak jakby byÅ‚a za daleko. Brakuje dosÅ‚ownie pÃ³Å‚ metra, aby wskoczyÄ‡ ale mina juÅ¼ bliÅ¼ej nie podchodzi.

PodsumowujÄ…c, gra to klasyczny Talos jednak w wersji VR doznamy duÅ¼o wiÄ™kszych emocji poprzez przeniesienie siÄ™ do Å›wiata Talosa. Dopiero tutaj moÅ¼na zobaczyÄ‡ jak ogromny jest ten Å›wiat i jak ogromne sÄ… obiekty ktÃ³re zwiedzaliÅ›my w klasyku (o ile oczywiÅ›cie miaÅ‚ ktoÅ› przyjemnoÅ›Ä‡ zagraÄ‡).

author: {'steamid': '76561198056444658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1476, 'last_played': 1596490643}
review:
Jedna z najlepszych gier w jakie graÅ‚em. Bardzo rozbudowana i ciekawa, zagadki takÅ¼e sÄ… mocnym punktem rozgrywki, w wiÄ™kszoÅ›ci niepowtarzalne ale skonstruowane tak aby byÅ‚y rozwiÄ…zywalne samodzielnie. Wersja VR poza kilkoma bÅ‚Ä™dami zwiÄ…zanymi z wysokoÅ›ciÄ… bohatera i moÅ¼liwoÅ›ciÄ… siÄ™gniÄ™cia po niektÃ³re elementy (ograniczenie najpewniej wprowadzone aby nie daÅ‚o siÄ™ "oszukaÄ‡" zagadek) jest dobrze przygotowana i moÅ¼na w niÄ… przyjemnie graÄ‡. Grafika przyjemna, rozgrywka pÅ‚ynna.

NajmocniejszÄ… stronÄ… gry jest jednak historia. Bardzo ciekawy pomysÅ‚, choÄ‡ wymaga nieco czytania aby w peÅ‚ni siÄ™ w niÄ… wciÄ…gnÄ…Ä‡. 

Bardzo polecam!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971880490', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1871, 'last_played': 1641267837}
review: This is now my favorite VR game. It's like portal but WAY better and much more fun. I'm sad I finished it. I looked forward to coming home from work and knocking out a few puzzles

author: {'steamid': '76561198264702671', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1649859909}
review:
This game is SERIOUSLY UNDERRATED.

Pros:
-Very good VR Port (Played on Oculus Rift)
-The Graphics are quite good and it makes for a zen like experience just taking in those beautiful Environments
-The puzzles are amazing and there are just soooo many of them
-The Game starts out pretty easy but gets decently hard towards the end
-Most of the story is optional, but i really recommend it, it is one of the deepest and most philosopical storys i have ever encountered in a game
-It doesn't get repetitive as new puzzle elements are unlocked at every stage

Cons:
-Multiple Savegames would have been nice
-The game lacks a clear indication when it saves your Progress (but tells you "Last Saved X Minutes ago" so i haven't lost any Progress to it)

Overall the game is amazing and completly UNDERRATED as in my Opinion it is as good if not even better than the Portal Series. All the Cons are fairly small and nothing that would be a deal breaker for me.
If you enjoyed Portal (who hasn't) you will probably like this game too.
I recommend you buying this right now, it is totally worth the price.
If you are unsure, the game is also often on sale for 5 bucks and thats a STEAL.

author: {'steamid': '76561198230227348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1707888018}
review: 10/10 better than any VR port Bethesda has ever touched

author: {'steamid': '76561198004655744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 2007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1677556082}
review:
Even after playing Half-Life: Alyx, this has been my most visually breathtaking VR experience. This was one of my favorite games of all time before the VR version, so to be there in VR is almost a dream come true. VR is the way I'd go for this game.

There are only a few drawbacks for this VR port, which are:

1. You can't carry two items at once, just like the flat version
2. Picking up the little tetris puzzle pieces used for opening doors or unlocking puzzle objects is more annoying than it needs to be
3. If your controllers go to sleep while the game is running and you wake them back up, the game menu might have trouble recognizing them
4. No ladder climbing animations

So no serious issues at all. In this game you explore various ancient ruins, including Egypt which is a place I've been to in person, and boy did Croteam do their research. It's like this game was made for VR, some of the visuals that were impressive in the flat game are just perfect in the VR version, most notably the tower.

The puzzle design of this game is some of my favorite of all time. They are as logical as it gets as every puzzle has a specific set of tools used to solve them, so you're working within confined rules making them the opposite of the abstract puzzles you see in other games like the Myst series. Every puzzle is a straightforward logical challenge so their complexity is very impressive and clever, most notably in Road to Gehenna which must have been designed by geniuses.

Everything including the puzzles, the computer terminals, the voice in the sky, it all ties back to one of the most thematically rich and emotionally powerful stories ever written for a game. The Talos Principle was always one of the least flawed masterpieces in gaming, and the VR version is the best way to experience it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186954897', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1595002954}

author: {'steamid': '76561198348245319', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1701534145}
review:
I have played the original PC version and absolutely loved it that I wanted to play it again. Being able to view the beautiful worlds in VR made it extremely worth it for me to buy again. 

I do have some concerns with controls, I couldn't figure out how to pick up connectors while preserving the connections I made. I couldn't figure out how to sprint, but I did find out that holding both grip buttons on the Oculus Touch controllers sped up in-game time. It's still a good port, but some changes could be made to the controls.

As for the ending, [spoiler] I didn't know how Croteam would achieve third person cutscenes in VR, but they managed to rework the scenes. I was a bit disappointed that they didn't do the scene with the zoom out revealing the outside and the EL Facility. I feel like they could've made this work by keeping the player stationary outside of the EL facility as the sun goes up to slowly reveal the EL facility and the world around it. It's understandable why they didn't add moving cameras, but I feel that they could've done better to maintain the original feel of the ending on the PC version. [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198228963564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1593495331}
review: I like the game, but it controls poorly and is nausea-inducing. VR doesn't seem like a good fit for The Talos Principle. I recommend getting the normal game instead. This version also has many more glitches, including one that forced me to restart from the beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041327268', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1707, 'last_played': 1634495456}
review:
The game is not made for VR, but that is partially a good thing. Many games that are VR-exclusive are short and gimmicky; making up for their lack of content by "being VR". This game is not like that. It stands on its own as a game, with the VR being a bonus added on top. The game doesn't benefit greatly from being VR, but it doesn't hurt either unless you are prone to "VR sickness". If you like me are used to VR movement and have a VR headset, then I recommend getting it for VR, otherwise the pancake version might suit better. I also can't guarantee that it runs well on all headsets. Personally, I had no major technical problems on my Rift CV1.

The graphics quality is decent, but environments are severely lacking in variety. The puzzles are perfectly fine, nothing revolutionary, but for the most part really enjoyable. And there are a lot of them. The game started slow with many easy puzzles at first, but the difficulty increases at the later stages and some of the puzzles (in particular some of the optional star puzzles) are pretty challenging. (I have yet to complete everything though, and I have not even touched "Road to Gehenna" yet.)

The philosophical discussions are above expectations in my opinion. I was worried that the game would force you to pick from a narrow set of viewpoints, lacking any real depth, and although there is some of that (thee is only so much you can fit in a finitely sized set of dialogue trees) it still posed questions that made me think - sometimes several minutes - before deciding which of the four or so options best represented my viewpoint. You can't expect maximum expressiveness, but as long as you are willing to compromise a little bit it allows for a surprising amount of introspection. The point is not to defend your world view, but to explore the options. I found that I often looked forward to the next discussion with the terminal when solving puzzles.

There were some instances where I accidentally solved some puzzles in a unintended ways; it is a bit too easy to break some levels. But at least you can't get yourself stuck, because you always have a reset-ability at your disposal.

Some minor technical problems that I experienced were some weird graphical bug when using paint cans which forced me to either restart the game or play around in the settings menu until it resolved itself. I ended up mostly avoiding the paint cans in the end. Some graphical options had weird results, but fortunately everything I cared about worked, including the default settings. Seated mode doesn't exist, but that didn't prevent me from sitting down anyway. Sure, I got "shorter", but that doesn't affect gameplay much.

Overall, this is one of my favorite puzzle games and it is for sure the best VR puzzle game I've played (although I have played very few VR puzzle games).

author: {'steamid': '76561198151526078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 3346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2426, 'last_played': 1620547656}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011639428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1593811200}
review: I'm in love all over again

author: {'steamid': '76561198052353402', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 860, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1265, 'last_played': 1593025170}
review:
The Talos Principles is one of the best first person puzzle games out there and being able to play it in VR with no graphical compromises is amazing. 

Pros:
+ It's the biggest VR puzzler: the whole original Talos + Road to Gehenna. The only thing missing is conversion of flat-screen workshop items. VR version has Steam workshop support, but there is nothing there
+ A lot of graphical and comfort settings, decent optimization

Cons:
- Almost everyone played flat-screen version and this is not the kind of game that you would replay. Luckily several years have passed since my initial playthrough, so I forgot almost every puzzle)
- There are few minor visual bugs, especially in Gehenna

author: {'steamid': '76561198025599358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1105, 'last_played': 1594262205}

review:
The Talos Principle is a good puzzle game, but I feel like it doesn't get much from being in VR.
It's also pretty sad that it is a standalone VR port, which means if you haven't bought it twice you can't switch between VR and non-VR,

author: {'steamid': '76561198067051062', 'num_games_owned': 1674, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1595039871}
review: While I'm not really sure if this game [i]needs[/i] to be VR, or how much it benefits from being in VR, there's definitely nothing [i]wrong[/i] with it.  It's a perfectly solid port.  If you liked the flat version, you'll like this version as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051285281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1697, 'last_played': 1592003342}
review: Wow, just wow. I got this game heavily discounted from the humble store and it is the best deal I've ever gotten. This game will make you question your own existence and contemplate life and death, along with providing excellently crafted puzzles and world building. Such a cool experience. The VR port is damn near perfect to boot. If your a fan of puzzles or just good storytelling, play this game.

If the controls were fixed I would rate this higher, but as it is, I have to rate at 6/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003308946', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1053, 'last_played': 1619437161}
review: would recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenge and who likes puzzles and philosophy. This game is obviously made with a lot of love. all of the levels are unique and very fun to play, but the best part is learning the story as it unfolds, conversations with the terminals are my favourite bit. you get a lot of game for your money and i would say its a good mix of logic and philosophy thought experiments with a good dose of sharp humour  havent finished it yet but looking forward to finishing it cant put it down

author: {'steamid': '76561198824276545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6379, 'last_played': 1619231458}
review: One of the best VR games I have every played. Great visuals and well-planned puzzles start off easy and get increasingly difficult (but not impossible) to solve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169094866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1680295313}
review:
Awesome graphics, and a lot of VR options customozations.
Very relaxing gameplay, and also works your braincells :) 
The philosophy / theology aspect is also interesting, and works your brain differently than the puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055147883', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1683074730}
review:
I'm only 2 hours in, yet... wow. Yes, the game hasn't been made for VR and it shows, but the immersion is astonishing.
I found myself stopping with any progression to enjoy the beautiful scenery and listen to the game's calming soundtrack so often I bet it took like half my total playtime.

Pros:
[list]
[*]The game is absolutely beautiful. The visuals are a bit dated and there is some visible model pop-in, but it still looks great.
[*]Amazing soundtrack
[*]Unlike most VR games, it doesn't feel like a tech demo, but a truly complete experience.
[*]It's one of the only games out there that natively supports Linux, and I can't thank the devs enough for that.
[*]I don't know much about the story yet due to my short playtime, but it's promising. I will update this review after I finish it.
[/list]

As for the cons, there are quite a few that I cannot overlook:
[list]
[*]It doesn't make much sense to stand in the game, yet it doesn't have a seated mode. You technically can change the world scale to better fit seated gameplay, but it's not a good solution. The devs mentioned on the forums that the vr_fDesiredVRHeadHeight config option should solve it, but it doesn't do anything for me. [u]We really need a working height slider in the options![/u]
[*]Door animations are glitchy - sometimes when I insert a key into a door, the opening animation doesn't play and it appears as the door stays closed. You can still go through it, so it doesn't break the gameplay, but it's annoying
[*]Low performance on Linux - I blame that on the flawed SteamVR implementation, so I think Croteam can't really do anything about it. If you're playing on Linux, expect some minor reprojection issues when looking at some areas. Nothing really bad, but worth mentioning.
[*]If you played the flat version, I don't think it's worth paying the full price again for essentially the same thing, just way more immersive. Thankfully, I haven't played it before.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197988839615', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1600481994}
review: A solid puzzle game in VR that ramps up in difficulty but never feels tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972104605', 'num_games_owned': 797, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1575081093}
review: Even though you have two hands, you can only use one at a time. This game was ported to VR "just because". They sell the same game as a new title just because it's in VR, but in my opinion, it's not justified. If you're interested in The Talos Principle, at least go with the non-VR version, it'll be more comfortable at least, since it's pretty much the same experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044806653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1584906921}
review: The Talos Principle is a fantastic game, but the concept of VR is entirely wasted here. I was hoping that they at least made some levels to take advantage of VR, but it's literally just the same game, no changes except you can move the camera with your head and teleport around. It's cool if you want to admire the scenery as if it were real life, but other than that you're better off just playing the standard version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038704419', 'num_games_owned': 640, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1245, 'last_played': 1587791236}
review: Good game to keep in the back of your mind while this covid-19 pandemic is going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065863581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1545249826}
review: First VR game where I felt dizzy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078361652', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1587072217}
review:
10 minutes. it took me 10 minutes to see how lazy this vr port is.

you see, the talos principle is probably one of the best games ever made. on a flat screen, its presentation, gameplay and storyline are all phenomenal.

in vr, however, the experience falls apart before it even begins. the opening cutscene is simply not there, and i suspect other cutscenes (which are few and far between I must admit) may also be missing. this is important because the big reveal at the end of the game is a flat cutscene. the base game looks fantastic for its age, but the graphics don't survive in vr. things are pixelated and blurry, models are jagged, plants are flat and fake looking. you can put your face inside anything that's not out of bounds, including cubes, jammers etc, but if you do physically walk out of bounds instead of blocking your view or something, you're jarringly and awkwardly teleported backwards. everything you can pick up is weightless and feels unpleasant to handle, things sticking to your hand rather than behaving like real objects.

[spoiler]and you know, i get it. the whole point of the talos principle is that the world [i]is[/i] fake. but a big part of that is how convincingly real everything looks at the beginning, so i fail to see this as any sort of excuse or scapegoat to have such a shoddy and shockingly lazy vr port.[/spoiler] it's buggy too - if i squeeze both of my hands into fists, all audio stops until i release them again. this is probably the best example i could find out of all the various ways the game manages to find in order to break or otherwise shatter your immersion.

i paid Â£4.49 for this on sale, and i've already asked for my money back. i cannot believe that they charge Â£30 for this normally. this is the absolute worst way to play talos principle, and charging just about Â£10 short of the new half life for that experience is anything from scummy through to stupid. don't waste your time, money or effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985605015', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1587341920}
review:
Warning to Index users. There's something very off with the bindings and the game was even auto walking without me touching ANYTHING on the remotes. It's always a problem when the controller tutorial interface shows vive controllers when you're holding index controllers.

Great pancake game, for now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048808881', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1587392750}
review:
Feels very beta like. As if they took a "flat" game and just added the VR option. Twice I had that my body and soul seperated, making me have an out of body experience(the 3d player model stood in place while I was able to walk around it).

Lot's of times I see things in the corners of my eyes, only to realise it is my body that somehow got seperated as well. I am a vivid member of an Indian tribe, but even in our trance we only should see our spirit animals, not ourselves!

ninja edit:  The game should keep your height in mind, I have to sqaut to reach every damn terminal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210052063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1548980252}
review:
A mediocre VR implementation of one of the greatest puzzle games ever. If this is your first time playing the Talos Principle, do yourself a favor and play the flat version.

This game was not made for VR and it shows. 

Cannot recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198041103929', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1561821210}
review:
It's a good port of the base game, but who was it made for exactly? It's not a game that feels more immersive in VR, you don't point guns or interact with stuff up close in tangible ways, the VR is very superfluous if you ask me.

Stick to the "flat" game honestly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001125375', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1585913147}
review: I just couldn't get used to the VR locomotion - wish they would use directional teleporting like Robo Recall. I gave up after about an hour. In the current state, I would much prefer to play the 2D version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277559200', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2047, 'last_played': 1587834263}
review: This game is easily on top of my VR list and among the best games I've ever played. Just play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970549386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1586651733}
review:
I wanted to like this game, having only ever played it in VR - the VR port has performance issues. I had to play it on medium settings on a valve index with a 2080ti and an i9 9900k. Even so, it looked rough, and no amount of super sampling seemed to help.

What's more, the control scheme actively seems to fight the index controllers, constantly grabbing objects and obstacles without meaning to. Overall a frustrating experience, and probably a better game in 2d.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059069448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1605405942}
review:
This game is sheer brilliance. It feels like exploring a labyrinth that Carl Sagan might write about. The atmosphere and tone of this game inspires awe and wonder towards human evolution. To top it off it's always a joy to have a dialogue with the serpent in the terminals about philosophy. The environments are beautiful and are that much more stunning experiencing it in VR.

The puzzles themselves are rather clever. Each section builds on previous knowledge and overtime become quite difficult. I've been struggling a great deal on many of the red piece areas but personally I think that makes the game worthwhile.

As far as being a VR port is concerned, Croteam did an excellent job. There are plenty of settings you can adjust for locomotion, comfort, etc. Obviously it would be amazing if the objects had realtime physics but considering this game was built for a flatscreen monitor initially they really did a fine job making everything functional for VR.

All in all this game is a unique, almost meditative experience. Definitely worth checking out if you find yourself wanting to try something with a relaxing pace and that will at times make you reflect on the larger questions in life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198870635735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 5876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4302, 'last_played': 1612679963}
review:
Ah, one of my favorite games to play in VR. But be warned - this game will either make you hurl or you'll develop a VR gut of steel.
Loved the Europe-inspired ruins. Such a beautiful and peaceful game to play. Get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041301654', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1552356742}
review: Flawless port of the original Talos Principle however the issues that game had are only magnified in VR, overlong campaign filled redundant puzzles makes keeping attention in VR even harder than ususal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141245660', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1711, 'last_played': 1675719398}
review: Worth every penny of the flat game and the VR version. When I was playing the flat version I was quite younger and more stupid so the puzzles were beyond me but I've got more brains now and can manage most of the puzzles on my own, which is nice. But the VR version is so well done, even if I have to lean up a bit from my seat to read the terminals. It's a beautiful game and, as always, terribly interesting. Also, excellent optimization of movement throughout, which is critical to a VR experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117028237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1075, 'last_played': 1634419840}
review:
This may be one of my favorite VR titles so far. The graphics are not the best and you can often see that it wasn't originally made with VR in mind, but it does not really break the immersion. Outside of playing the game itself, some of the worlds are also nice for short, relaxing getaways when, say, you are stuck at home for a long time during a pandemic. :))

The game mechanics are perfectly suited for VR. I can't really imagine going back to mouse + keyboard with this one. Compared to other VR games, this port also naturally comes with a lot of content, which is something that many pre-2020 VR games made from scratch were missing.

Few hours in, the puzzles are still somewhat easy, but I expect them to get harder in time. The story and / or lore also seems interesting so far, and I love the short philosofical texts and stories along the way. Definitely recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046077368', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1213, 'last_played': 1577187040}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045831026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1589764533}
review: I want to like this game but have never gotten it to even play on steam vr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198222423736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1667964120}
review: It actually stumped me every now and then. Good puzzle game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991202316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1515696068}
review:
The puzzles in this are great! The story was intriguing, although unoriginal. This was a game that was always in the back-burner to pick up. Once it was on VR I decided that it was one of the first I wanted to get. Booting it up I found the creators put a lot of time an energy into making it tolerable to motion sickness. This probably should have been a warning sign.

I'm actually pretty good with VR not getting motion sick at all. I've spent hours in other VR Games. However... I don't know what it is about the graphics but I found it unplayable. At most I could spend 15 minutes before needing to stop and catch a breather. I went with the clunky but less sick inducing motion and setup. I've hosted game nights with VR and every player who played this couldn't last as long as I did. I just can't recommend this at risk of actual sickness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060528572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1585397481}
review:
I really liked the difficulty of the puzzles and even though there are so many puzzles you almost have to use a different approach for each puzzle. It does not get repetitive at all. The story was intriguing . The narrator actually gave me goosebumps here and there.
On the other hand, I have played it on Oculus Rift. Grabbing and handling items on VR was a nightmare throughout the game. At some point, I had to play with game settings ,switch from teleport to locomotion, just to pass one of the levels. I was on a mine travelling and I had to grab a box which was not possible with the teleport set up for some reason. In addition, I kept losing the sound while I was holding items as well.

Great game but was not very pleasant to play it on Oculus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077173611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1532, 'last_played': 1584317176}
review:
After some slightly uninspired opening hours, this turned out to be pretty ace :)

[h1]To VR Or Not To VR?:[/h1]

VR elevates a bunch of the existing qualities here. The hand-held devices, physics interactions, and 'jungle gym' puzzle solving put you right in the centre of the action. It makes for a fun mix of cerebral tinkering followed by active enacting. (And occasionally combines the two. There's something to be said for soaring 20ft up on a column of air to get a bird's eye view of the puzzle ;))

The Cryengine locations form a lovely expansive backdrop (even if the 'photo realistic' style can't always survive you nosing right up to its more budget bump-maps). And the whole 'ghost in the machine' / 'simulated world' story gains some extra vibe when you're actually injected into those digital spaces ;)


[h1]It's A Laser Trap:[/h1]

The five core tools that you unlock aren't the only way they keep things fresh, with further twists arriving downstream. There are a few moments were they over-rely on the core techniques though. (Oh, more laser-round-an-impossible-corner conundrums?). But just as frequently they'll surprise you by making a novel physical interaction the crux of the next map, or add a new use for an environmental hazard instead.

As a puzzle game, the key thing for me was: I frequently stood in the middle of these breezy virtual spaces, hands on hips, and said: 'That's impossible'. And then worked it out anyway. Sometimes multiple times in one map . They've got the 'make you feel smart' thing pretty nailed down, with only perhaps one or two maps that bordered on feeling unfair / frustrating.


[h1]If A Story Is Trapped In A Box, Is It Really There?[/h1]

The primarily text-based story is almost entirely optional, but I found myself welcoming the dips into the computer terminals in every realm. It does help if you like ancient philosophy, arguing theology, AI ethics, and pondering the nature of 'self' though 

Not that their archive of mythical excerpts and a 'chose from these answers' interface can really encompass this spread of dialectic disagreements and contemporary mysteries. But they have a damn good go 


---

[h1]Too Long Didn't Read Your Metaphysical Treatise:[/h1]

[b]Positives:[/b]
[list][*]Tons of content, scaling over time, with various flavours of twists to the trickiness.
[*]A playful nested story that taps into themes of consciousness, free will, ethics and theology. And then occasionally sticks its tongue out at you 
[*]Lovely settings and audio work.[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list][*]Slow, slightly insipid, start.
[*]A couple of unintuitive story twists can leave you locked out of further progression, having to restart from a few saves back. It's clunky. (Hint: If you 'exit' from a story terminal you often can't turn it back on...)[/list]

[b]Motion Comfort:[/b]
[list][*]Despite the consummate control options, you may need your VR legs to deal with some of the shunts and jumps involved when boxes misplace or airstreams propel you sideways through the air...[/list]

[h1]Postscript:[/h1]

And I'm still going with the free DLC content, which has kept the difficulty fiendishly ramped up, and given the story some new fun twists 

---

4+ [nausea possible]

author: {'steamid': '76561197980722015', 'num_games_owned': 744, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1582215710}
review: It finally works flawlessly with the index controllers and the performance is greatly improved as well. I've already played this game to death in 2D and VR is neat but it doesn't add much to the gameplay. It's a shame no one uses the Cryengine for VR games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969284508', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1586577926}
review: I fully completed Talos Principle on flatscreen and I absolutely love it, it's a masterpiece. I got the VR version in order to play the Road to Gehenna DLC. Looking good so far!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079074554', 'num_games_owned': 342, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1586749819}
review:
Id say this is one of the best VR games there is, the port works great. The price is a bit steep if you own the flat version though, but well worth it anyway. Game looks amazing in VR, you really get a sense for how big everything is. And the controls are good. Something i miss is locking your height so you dont feel like a dwarf when you play seated, since it is a quite long game to be standing up.

Also, you can use the save file from the flat version of the game which is a huge plus

author: {'steamid': '76561198113653131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1585265000}
review: Good little puzzle game, the computer religious texts were a little unexpected, the game seems to have some sort of religious theme  running through it everything from Hebrew to Aztec it would appear. Bur that does not detract from the game play which is essentially solving puzzles and collecting sidguels which are coloured shapes you use to open gateways to  other places and more puzzles and more siduels. The locations are impressive and some of the puzzles are tricky to solve not as straight forward as they first appear but do able and fun. Spent 4 hours on it so far and reckon there is a fair way to go before what ever the point is is made clear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020416096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1470, 'last_played': 1583079108}
review: Excellent level design, great brain teaser puzzles - some of which require out of the box thinking. The story is very philosophical, and the VR aspect of the game adds a lot to the experience. Very well made VR port and it is great to play on the Valve Index. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050672642', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 5102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1653, 'last_played': 1706476443}
review:
[b]Index Controller mapping solution at the end![/b]
This is the single greatest VR title I have played so far. The story is amazing (DON'T skip the terminals!), the VR port is simply leagues above anything else out there and the menu options make sure anyone is able to set it exactly as they want to.
I spent maybe 30 hours in the game (finished all endings yesterday, now I'm going for the DLC).
When I got to the pets.html article it really got to me... I guess I am [spoiler]comfortable with all humanity going extinct but get very emotional over a few hungry cats[/spoiler] :D

The only problem is Index Controller mapping, which by default jumps when you grip harder. So you pick up an object and as you grip harder, you jump. Fortunatelly, this can be reconfigured in SteamVR settings in Controller/Custom mapping. I just removed that jump action from the Grip event and saved as my own mapping. The game will reset to the original mapping each time you start it, but you can just switch to your custom (by then saved) mapping and game on. It takes 30 seconds. It's definitely annoying and I guess kinda big oversight (or maybe dev abandonment), but I am willing to put up with it as the game is SO FREAKING GOOD!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018060714', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1184, 'last_played': 1581575194}
review: A must have if you enjoy puzzle games. Runs flawlessly on the Rift CV1, controls work great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968830351', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1651, 'last_played': 1582688331}
review: Most fun I have had in VR to date. If you enjoyed portal, this is the best VR equivalent. Only one puzzle I would say was one unfair. The other 3 I needed google with...well....those are on me. Story was shockingly great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161202424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1577484106}
review: Was excited to play this game, love the studio's last releases. Honestly disappointed! :(  Looks very nice and the controls work well, just found the puzzles a bit boring. 3 stars at best....Sorry Croteam, love ya!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972140284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2215, 'last_played': 1687027543}
review:
[h1]"Buy me." (Experienced with the Valve Index HMD & Controllers[/h1]

The VR version of this game, as usual, adds a great deal of enjoyment to the game (the usual headtracking + stereoscopy boost, with some natural grab/finger-tracking added to the control scheme).

[i]I originally played the non-VR version minus extended content.[/i]

Both versions are identical aside from some input options and a single cutscene/angle which was, for whatever reason, MIA during my playthrough (non-issue, really).

The Index version includes finger-tracking which provides effortless input in a few cases, but somewhat problematic in some of the extended content which had not yet been fully optimized for it. Either way, as is usually the case, I can't see anything being able to beat the experience of the Index (especially if the game also has lifelike audio. . . unfortunately, this game does not, but the Index's off-ears are always great, regardless).

If you haven't played Talos, the game really [i]is[/i] a [i]must[/i] buy. The puzzles are fun. . .but the story is fantastic -- even if it finds itself "preaching to the converted". . .or perhaps, especially in this case; it's very nice to see a game that's-, oddly enough, based firmly in reality. . . in a way (it's as real, and meaningful as things get, story wise...a real breath of fresh air in this medium).

Parting note: I don't play with the English voice-over (I find it. . .distracting, maybe even. . .unfitting). I have enjoyed the game most in a spoken language I'm familiar with, but not at all fluent in -- with subtitles enabled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198960691005', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2176, 'last_played': 1587681241}
review: I wish this game was more popular. The seemingly infinite number of puzzles is shocking! So many views and references with just the right amount of story. I love it! Thx Croteam!

author: {'steamid': '76561198831913636', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1698948443}
review:

Overall this is a fantastic game.

review: Bei "The Talos Principle VR" handelt es sich um ein wunderschÃ¶nes RÃ¤tsel-Spiel, das mit vielen philosophischen Elementen in unterschiedlichsten Erscheinungsformen bereichert ist. Es ist fast wie Urlaub, wenn man abends nach Feierabend noch "mal eben" zwei, drei Stunden sich in die Talos-Welt begibt und RÃ¤tsel lÃ¶st oder auch mal einfach nur durch die sehr schÃ¶n gestaltete Landschaft wandert und diese auf sich wirken lÃ¤sst. Gewundert habe ich mich, dass das Spiel ursprÃ¼nglich nur fÃ¼r Bildschirm entwickelt worden ist und erst spÃ¤ter nach VR portiert wurde. Ich kann mir kaum vorstellen, wie man "The Talos Principle" nicht als VR-Spiel spielen kann. Es lebt ja geradezu davon, sich mitten in der Welt zu befinden und auch so die RÃ¤tsel zu lÃ¶sen oder die Welten zu erleben und zu genieÃŸen. Das Spiel habe ich wÃ¤hrend einer Aktion fÃ¼r unter sechs Euro erhalten, aber es ist definitiv aus meiner Sicht auch den realen Kaufpreis wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075799424', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1603802332}
review:
The sense of presence is acute in this game. Playing through the gloriously sunny opening level in the depth of a Scottish winter is a powerful reminder of how immersive VR can be. 

Would visit again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076790219', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1580074537}
review:
Played the flat screen version, loved it. Bought the VR version as soon as I got my Rift S.  
The VR version is literally the exact same game BUT IN VR!  
Totally worth it even if you played the flat screen. Only gripe is the performance isn't the best. After playing around with settings I found that ultra everything except for shadow trilinear filtering gives me a solid 40 fps with perfect frame time. Makes the game feel smooth and I don't notice that it's 40 fps. The game says 40 FPS at least...  
I can definitely notice when a game drops from 75 fps to 60 so it's strange I dont notice the 40 fps

review: This game is incredible. Challenging puzzles, beautifully crafted worlds, and an absolutely fantastic soundtrack. I had this game in my library for an entire year before finally playing it, and I was absolutely hooked. Played for almost 40 hours in the span of about 2 weeks to completely finish the game, and I haven't even played the DLC yet! I would absolutely have paid full price for this, but when it's on sale it's a no-brainer. For anyone wanting a portal-esque VR experience, this is it.

review:
this is bad VR adaptation of very intresting game 

After some time there is grafic bug which changes colors. I discovered at steam forums that it occurs since long time.
There is walkaround to fix this but it make even more bugs.

Game is poorly adjusted for [b]Valve Index[/b] any button triggers teleportation it is flustrating to die because you accidentally teleport in death zone insted of rotate. There is no option to change key mapping

author: {'steamid': '76561198263463672', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1584812871}
review: One of my favorite VR experiences. The puzzles of very fun and satisfying, the world is beautiful and has a lot of graphical settings allowing lower end as well as higher end PC's to run it, the world seems pretty expansive and is worth a try on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198977566412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 2347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1600625437}
review:
There is a lot to do, but in quite repeating fashion.  There is nice and exiting story, but it involves quite much low resolution reading in VR. Controller setting do need some work and reasonable controls do cause quite high level of motion sickness ( I don not feel any sickness in most games ).

I can imagine far better VR games, but only Beat Saber is better that this one in my library .

Bye if you like puzzle games and do not have any motion sickness in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062545351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1578500176}
review:
6/10. The game became unplayable.

Pro:
- Many kinds of puzzle
- Compared with others puzzle games, it is a long game (7h, I am in the half, without taking help from internet)
- Good history.
- A lot of creativity to make a game so fun and envolving.

Cons:
- It has a teleport gameplay, sometimes I pressed the wrong button and died, back to the start for no reason
-The "recorder"made this thing unplayable. Need a "stop" buttom, at least.
- It uses engine and effects from Serious Sam. It is not exactly a bad thing, only if you play it before playing The Talos Principle. I was startled, thinking when it would appear some scary monster while I am without weapons.

No monster in the game, of course.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111577313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1550206633}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041737972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1581943031}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969827674', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1584759156}
review:
I hate to do this because this is a good port and a great game but the current version's Index controller support is broken and the devs appear to have abandoned the game.

They were active on the forums but are not responding now and don't appear interested in fixing the problem.

The issue is that pressing the grips causes the player to jump. This means you go around jumping constantly when you just want to perform simple actions even though jump is already assigned to the A button. You also cannot unmap the touch bad from locomotion meaning you are constantly moving around by accident when you don't want to.

There are also issues with jumping on some Oculus controllers.

Do not buy this game until the devs address these issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064743380', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1583297686}
review:
â–ºTHIS = (Portal's mind twisting puzzles) + (beautiful ancient ruins) in VR
â–ºVoted in 'Top VR Hidden Gems you didn't know about' @ JoinUsInVR Group (Key Giveaways) 

An amazing game.  I played it in 2D and just started the 3D in VR.  This feels like it was made for VR !

-----------DETAILED REVIEW-----------
[quote]
BY: Ghanth (JoinUsInVR member)
READ FULL:  https://steamcommunity.com/id/Ghanth/recommended/552440/

Playing The Talos Principle in VR is like hacking your own consciousness. Yes, you have a brain. And you also have two hands that let you interact with this strange anachronic world of ancient ruins and technology. And you will learn it has great plans for you.

You'll go for an introspective journey that'll help you unfold your Metaphysical intelligence. The puzzles are incredibly clever and often requires you to think out of the box you were comfortable within.

You could also find yourself have a stop just to contemplate the shadows of the upper clouds sliding on those beautiful sceneries or be impressed by the gigantic size of this tower... Magical moments of VR.

The lifetime of the game is pretty larger than what we were used to up to now in VR and the VR version also includes Road to Gahenna DLC wich is awesome too.

Plus Croteam refused to fall into the wall garden strategy trap that FB/Oculus was offering them. So it's still available here for every VR player today. We, as users, could reward this attitude if we care about standing for freedom of choice in this merciless world.

That's a fair price in regards to what a good VR portage it is, and VR definitely unleash the beauty of this existential work of art. [/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198025774571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1560041608}

author: {'steamid': '76561198211540888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 3379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1634, 'last_played': 1584317503}
review: One of my favourite games in VR.  Great puzzle game reminiscent of Portal and Portal 2, but with even more of a philosophical feel to it.  It is also really pretty in VR.  Finished the DLC too.  Highly recommend!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038249667', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1575683956}
review:
The VR port of the game is just not that good. Simple problems like standing on a stair-step making the camera move up and down, which is headache inducing in VR, add up really fast resulting in a experience that is just not enjoyable. The game also uses too much text written in small letters to convey a story. It's already bad on the Index, I can't imagine how hard it is to read on a Vive or Oculus.

I think you are better off getting the non-vr version. The puzzles seemed interesting enough, and the story intriguing. Only the VR implementation was lacking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198980888515', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 4214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1979, 'last_played': 1606113513}
review: The game is AMAZING.  30 or 40 hours of really great puzzles and scenery. In my top 3 favorite VR titles.   I really think you are an idiot if you don't buy this game, considering it keeps getting packaged at extreme discounts with the Serious Sams, which are all also amazing mindless VR shooters.  Bonus if you like Serious Sam, since some of the Egyptian scenery pops up in Talos as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086094471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1572161211}
review:
Do NOT buy this if you own an Oculus Rift S!

I didn't check the tags to see that this specifically the S is unsupported; the image as you move around only changes in one eye leaving you nauseated and unplayable.

Developer support only checks their email every 2 weeks, and says they're working on Oculus Rift S support. This headset release 9 months ago! 

Don't make my mistake, this game sat in my library before I tried to play it so I'm inelligible for a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147665201', 'num_games_owned': 36, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1600957203}
review:
I don't know how to describe how good this game is.
It's long
It indroduces you to the mechanics slowly
It has a deep meaning (I study Philosophy... It's literally condensed Metaphysics)
The only problem? Some poor optimization... It runs fine on ryzen 1600 and r9 390 but i have to turn down cpu settings especially

What are you waiting for? Show the devs some love by buying this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198265048136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1349, 'last_played': 1584401963}
review:
Having just completed The Talos Principle I feel I have experienced enough to review the game. 

My first impression was it looks stunning. I have a fairly high end setup and ran everything in ultra which may have helped. The first world is reasonably large and the game takes you through the first easy tutorial levels without it feeling too forced. The puzzle pieces themselves are not new lazers, blocks & switches and there are a few baddies orbs and guns. I didn't have any trouble getting into the game and getting solving. I think I cleared 2/3 of the first world in about 3 hours, including some exploring of the wider areas.

Then things start to get tricky. There are a few more tools to play with and some far more complex puzzles. One mistake I made was to stop for a few weeks then went back to it. I'd forgotten a few key tricks and that made working out some of the later puzzles much harder than they needed to be. Though tricky they rarely felt impossible and I only came close to reaching for a walk through twice. I'm not sure if it's a spoiler but every puzzle is contained in its box, getting stars on the other hand often requires thinking outside the box.

As you get used to the style of puzzles the story and philosophies discussed in Talos do become more engaging. I liked listening to what she had to say and reading the material was an interesting break that adds to the feeling of progression more than just "here comes another puzzle". Talking to the serpent did bug me occasionally because sometimes you're limited to a small number of unhelpful responses, but its only for a bit and it gets better. And personally I'm not overly keen on the getting killed by baddies in puzzle games. Really a baddie is not much different to a door (i.e. you can't pass till you get the key) but they reset all the solution you had so far. So you have to redo the part of the solution you already puzzled out. Not so bad at the start but when it's the last thing and you get caught on a wall or rotate accidentally it feels like you've been cheated.

Given the subject matter it shouldn't be surprising but I found it made me feel quite lonely on occasion!

There were only a few  puzzles where I felt the answer relied too heavily on precise placements or dodgy physics (maybe there was a better answer) and I could forgive it because they were rare and the sense of achievement from completing a puzzle that has had you stumped is always good.

In short it's a good puzzle game with an engaging story and well worth the asking price.

Now to get stuck into Road to Genhennena... Genheyar... Guinea pig... the other set of puzzles that come with The Talos Principle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978863243', 'num_games_owned': 944, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1636701077}
review:
SintiÃ©ndolo mucho, le tengo que dar una manita para abajo. El juego en sÃ­ es muy bueno, y jugarlo en VR con la sensaciÃ³n de estar en esos bucÃ³licos escenarios estÃ¡ genial. Pero en la ficha del juego se indica claramente que se puede jugar sentado, y eso es mentira, al menos si juegas con un Rift S. Y es que si juegas sentado con este visor, tu vista estarÃ¡ muy cerca del suelo, y eso ademÃ¡s de molesto, te hace imposible interactuar con cosas como los monitores o algunos puzzles. Es un juego de muchas horas, y quiero jugarlo sentado, ademÃ¡s de que me gusta jugar con desplazamiento libre y me marea un poco de pie, no asÃ­ sentado. En las opciones del juego no hay posibilidad de indicarle al juego una altura o si estÃ¡s jugando sentado, solo una opciÃ³n de escala del mundo que lo que hace es hacer mÃ¡s grande o pequeÃ±o el mundo en general, pero no sirve para esto. Si no se puede jugar sentado, Â¿por quÃ© mienten en la ficha? 

En realidad, con otros visores si se puede, ademÃ¡s de Rift S tengo un WMR de HP, con estas como le indico desde la configuraciÃ³n del visor la altura que yo quiera, pues le pongo mi altura en la posiciÃ³n sentada, y entonces en el juego es como si estuviese de pie aun estando sentado. Pero quiero jugar con mi Rift S, que se ven mejor y el tracking es mejor, pero no puedo, a no ser que sea de pie, que no es por pereza, es por lo que he dicho antes. Rift S lleva ya unos cuantos meses en el mercado y sus desarrolladores no se han dignado en hacer nada, asÃ­ que lo dicho, es un gran juego, pero le tengo que dar una opiniÃ³n negativa.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970826049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1199, 'last_played': 1574701167}
review:
Really good VR Game. Great design, nice photo realism, good concept.  Puzzles range from the easy to very hard. Take it at your own pace.. no-gore or violence (at least so far). Maybe a little repetitive but with enough mystery to keep you going on. Bought on sale and very glad I did as I love these sorts of game. Portal lovers will probably love this. Its portal with a twist, as it it hadn't been twisted enough.

Pros.. Gave me a head ache.. a good headache.. the ache of cogs turning as some of this requires you to think quite hard about it. Really realistic design. Thought provoking in places. A couple of "WTF.. that's wicked" moments..

Cons.. the VR interface could be better. More of a port than a VR game - jumping is awful but thankfully workable.  Couple of gui bugs (annoyances) but nothing game breaking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014706658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1604864330}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970282042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1577752423}
review:
Bought this for flat screen originally and really liked it, but was undecided about getting the VR edition at the full price. But just happen to catch it on sale and took the plunge. Glad I did! Very immersive and so different actually standing right there in the game/puzzles. It seems weird and maybe cause have a good idea what to do, but certainly don't remember all the ways to  beat the puzzles, but actually seems easier seeing them right there in front of you. At least so far. 

Still probably worth it at full price if you already own the flat screen version, it is a fantastic deal on sale either way though. The sale only has 16 hours left at this time. So get it if was on the fence. It is fun and immersive.

The Controls are little harder to get use to from using the keyboard and mouse, but caught on pretty quickly. Using the Index so far has been easy. The default ones don't have jump so will see if need that functionality or not later, but so far not. The graphics and sound are amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019282902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1573483468}
review: Not quite ready for Index users yet. I am usually pretty good at picking up even complex control schemes for games but the Index controls are completely unintuitive and almost broken to the point of ruining the game for me. After much playing I eventually realised that I kept dying because I was hard grabbing objects which makes you teleport and causes you to drop what you grabbed. This usually resulted in a frustrating death. If the controls can be fixed (or at least made mappable by the user) then I would reconsider my review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965771914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3026, 'last_played': 1572464494}
review:
It's an amazing game and it works very well in VR (Oculus).
I'm lucky to be able to play it in full motion (smooth walking, smooth turning).

This game is and was the best in puzzles. Great environments, gorgeous soundtrack.
The puzzles are indeed challenging but they are fair.

If there is anything negative to say about it, then it's the replayability. But it turns out that I forget enough of the solutions to have another enjoyable go every two years or so. ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032632811', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 758, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1569899886}
review: A glitchy and uncomfortable way to play an otherwise clever, but drawn out and visually drab, puzzle game that gains no additional depth from operating in VR. Making this shabby port into a separate purchase presents a disorienting choice to incoming VR-compatible players. Seeing as puzzle games carry limited replayability once you know the answers, isolating each of the identical versions for players who are only going to own only one copy was a slightly degrading action. I wouldnâ€™t look twice at the chance to play the original game with its appropriate interface and its (hopefully) more stable state, but itâ€™d be odd to pay for the same game, on the same platform, with a different camera angle.
