author: {'steamid': '76561197975387628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1580998835}
review:
I already owned the non-VR version, and I wrote a review of it. Since the exact same review still applies, I'm going to copy-paste it here. However, before that some comments about this VR version.

Firstly, for anybody who already owns the original non-VR version, be advised: This is *exactly* the same game as the original, with the exact same content. The only difference is that it's in stereoscopic VR, with VR controls. However, that being said, if it has been a long time since you played the original (as was my case) it may still be worth to grab this, in order to re-experience the game in VR.

Secondly, many people are saying in their reviews that this has poor support for Oculus Rift controllers. I don't understand what they are saying since that's not my experience at all. I have the Oculus Rift S, and the game plays perfectly with it. I have not noticed any issues of any kind.

The game can be controlled with the "teleporting" mechanic, or with the free-movement mechanic (ie. you move with the left joystick, as with any FPS game). The camera can be rotated with the right stick, either as normal, or in steps (45 degrees) for comfort. Personally I find this mode of control (free movement with left stick, rotation in steps with right stick) the best. (I do not suffer any sort of motion sickness in this mode, no matter how fast I move in game with the left stick.) It can be played sitting down or standing up. (I recommend a rotating chair, if sitting down.)

Given that the original game looks quite beautiful, and the VR version uses the same graphics, it makes this one of the best-looking VR games out there, which is really nice. It might need a relatively hefty PC to run smoothly, though (I myself have a high-end i9 CPU and a GTX 1080, and the game works very smoothly, with only really rare hiccups sometimes. They happen so rarely that they aren't bothersome.)

My original review of the non-VR game:

During the past few years I have played many, many games, the vast majority of them being mediocre, and even the best of them being just "ok". Too often have I felt that game developers are running out of ideas, or lack the talent to make a good idea into a great game... Too often have I felt that playing a game through is more a chore than a delight.

The Talos Principle, however, feels like a breath of fresh air. It has been a really long time since I have felt so enthralled by a video game, since I have been so involved and so addicted with a game that I have to play for hours to discover what new the game has to offer, since I have been so motivated to find every single secret, and solve every single puzzle even if optional.

Among countless mediocre and ok at best video games that inundate the market, The Talos Principle is certainly a gem. It might not be for everybody, but it certainly was for me.

If you liked Portal and Portal 2, chances are that you will like this. It's somewhat similar in gameplay and even in idea, but certainly without being a ripoff or clone in any significant way.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. In my books it's one of the best games made in recent years. Heck, one of the best games ever. Definitely in my personal top 10 games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273770465', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1432, 'last_played': 1681347750}
review: nice

author: {'steamid': '76561197979631396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1573, 'last_played': 1614759558}
review:
This is one of those games where you get to the end (presumably) and decide not to finish until you've done everything else because you just don't want it to end. I still haven't climbed the tower. The Talos Principle must not apply.

The environment is perfect for VR. It can be hard to max out without reprojection though, so having an Index in 144hz mode really helps since then it drops to 72fps instead of 60 or if you have a Rift S what.. 40?(!)fps. I have a pretty powerful PC but without risking pop-in with the LoD, at native res, I still can't keep things at a lofty framerate without reprojection. Such is VR though. Having full finger control is pretty great too though and it works well.

My only complaints are the autotargeting of placing objects can suck, and having grip be Grab AND Jump was an odd decision. There's already the A button for Jump so I have accidentally moved while attempting to pick up an object dozens of times. Also needing to keep your finger on the track pad when placing sigils in the door puzzles seems like a bad holdover from Vive Wand controls.

Other than that this game has been one of my favorite experiences period.

Oh yeah and if you do try the game, just know the opening section gives a bad first impression. The first area is graphically the worst and the puzzles are simpler than need be. It picks up after you go up the elevator.

review: Ho affrontato questa esperienza nella modalitÃ  VR con Oculus Rift e l'ho adorato. E' un gioco che probabilmente non avrei mai acquistato per giocarci su monitor, sbagliando, poichÃ¨ la trama Ã¨ un qualcosa di intrigante, profondo e toccante. Inutile dire che giocato in prima persona Ã¨ stato fantastico poichÃ¨ la grafica Ã¨ una delle migliori che ho provato sin ora su VR (1080 impostando tutto a palla) e soprattutto Ã¨ un gioco con ambientazioni che lasciano spesso a bocca aperta, con musiche di atmosfera anche se ripetitive a volte. Non essendo un gioco frenetico dove c'Ã¨ da sparare me lo sono goduto appieno sfruttando il movimento libero (soffro pochissimo il motion sickness) dando cosÃ¬ un senso di immersivitÃ  impareggiabile e le ore che ci ho giocato lo dimostrano. Da dicembre ho scaricato molti altri giochi per vr, di vario genere, ma questo mi ha tenuto incollato piÃ¹ degli altri, che per un motivo o per l'altro ho abbandonato dopo un ora. Ho finito ieri anche il dlc e merita tantissimo pure lui, specialmente per le vertigini che mi ha fatto provare facendo certi salti..chi non ha provato mai un VR non puÃ² capire cosa si prova a buttarsi nel vuoto da un ponte, seppur virtuale! E' un genere che non avevo mai provato e sono rimasto sorpreso perchÃ¨ il senso di appagamento nel risolvere gli enigmi Ã¨ stato notevole e la frustrazione si Ã¨ presentata di rado. Se avete un VR non fatevelo scappare, probabilmente a livello di immersivitÃ  e appagamento grafico non esiste di meglio sul mercato, a patto di non abbandonarlo alle prime difficoltÃ , perchÃ¨ la storia si fa intrigante dopo qualche ora. I brividi che mi ha regalato non li dimenticherÃ²!

author: {'steamid': '76561198335465084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12080, 'last_played': 1560969638}
review: I am only partway through thus far but this is by far one of the best VR experiences. The  environments are stunning, the music is lovely, the puzzles so far have been fun yet challenging (though I fear I'm approaching walkthrough territory soon), and the AI/sci-fi and philosophical elements are awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017706666', 'num_games_owned': 1228, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1508295904}
review: It's the Talos Principle in VR. While it's too bad that they didn't create some VR-specific levels, it's a good port of the original game and the original game is fantastic. Get whichever version you want and you should enjoy the heck out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966401809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1508264753}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051468974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1703537364}
review:
First off, I've had the pleasure to enjoy this experience on the Oculus Rift CV1 paired with an RTX 2070. Runs well enough, especially given the sorcery that is asynchronous timewarp.

I mean sure, whenever I looked on the backside off my right hand there was a huge black rectangle blocking basically everything, the controls were unintuitive at best and somewhere around 20hrs in a patch landed reconfiguring the controls which I had internalized by then. Go figure. 

Now, just after 33 hours, I'm pretty positive I've got all sigils and stars from the main game as well as Road to Gehenna. You could say I've made it to the hall of fame, which took me quite by surprise.
But let's be honest, I had to look up the eagle's landing just like everyone else. The rest was all me, though.

But all in all, what's my verdict? The VR implementation feels rushed and unpolished, the puzzles are not for everyone and some can be quite maddening. The story will not allow you to major in any kind of philosophics course and coop is basically just you playing with yourself. 
You here for any of that? Well, buy it anyways, keep your mind open, answer as you actually would when asked and just be part of the world you'll find yourself in. You might just learn something or another about yourself. I sure did.
And even though the graphics are quite a bit dated nowadays; the visuals are plain stunning. Same goes for the amazing soundtrack. And the terminals. Especially the terminals.

These 33 hours will not be my final time for this experience. I still need to take a friend with me, even though he declined the first time around; and I'll try not to be as stubborn with strangers in far lands from now on.
But for now? I think @ has the right idea. I'm just going to rest here for a while, enjoy the tranquility.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990914884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1566532400}
review:
Best starter VR game if you are looking to get your VR legs. This title has so many options besides teleportation: Zoom, blink Teleport, controller style movement with vignetting, and of course the goal which is the same without the vignetting. 

Also the game itself is amazing. Great assets that were designed as objects rather than flat textures make a game look better on a monitor, but in VR this truly brings a world to life.

Like Portal, this is a puzzle game that puts a focus on the story and world. 
Progression is the famous Mario 64 style that is yet to be beat, allowing you to move on to new worlds but comeback later for the more difficult 'stars'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198384348844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 36618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12188, 'last_played': 1640299940}
review: 200 hours on this game, and enjoyed all of them. Fantastic game with fair (and sometimes difficult) puzzles. There are 40 to 60 puzzles total in which you must incorporate signal jammers, force field screens, power connecters in three separate worlds (and ancient cultures).  World B was my favourite by far.  I would've liked to have seen some Inca or Aztec ruins too and jungle features, but hey, it's great as it is still. The storyline is weak, and there were times I wanted to smash the computers. Also, after 25 similar puzzles, they do start to wear on you but I was glad that at least they were all different from puzzle to puzzle. Kind of like Mexican food: same ingredients- different dish. Regardless, I spent my two week vacation (Master's in Addiction Counseling) playing this game and had a blast. One of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. I waited until it was 50% off, so it was definitely worth the money. Here's a tip for you: if you want to buy a game at a reduced price, put it on your wishlist. (Every game I've ever wishisted has gone on sale within just a few weeks afterwards.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198016685578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1685109628}
review:
Wo fange ich an? 
01.: Die Grafik auf der W.M.R sieht spitze aus.
02.: Die Sprachaugabe in Deutsch ist super Klasse. (Ein Lob an die Synchronsprecher und Tonstudio, steht dem Originale in Nichts nach.)
03.: Die Steurung lÃ¤sst sich wirklich sehr gut konfigurieren, alle WÃ¼nsche offen.
04.: FÃ¼r Knobelfans ist an alles gedacht, bisher kaum Zeitlimits, man kann sich alles genau anschauen.
05.: Es basiert weitesgehenst auf physikalischer Basis. (Kein Kreuzen von Lichtstrahlen, etc.) Also alles logisch wie ich es liebe.
06.: Es wird eine Geschichte darum erzÃ¤hlt, da kommt wieder die Vertonung ins Spiel.
07.: Man merkt das mit der gegeben Welt was nicht stimmt, alÃ¢ Matrix also "forscht" man weiter.
08.: Die Idee mit den C64 am jeweiligen Level Start (oder Ã¤hnliches) den man abfragen kann verdichtet die Story.
09.: Man wird "seicht" in die kommenden Aufgaben invulviert, kein "Was ist das denn jetzt?"
10.: Obwohl wenig erklÃ¤rt wird wie es denn nun weiter geht ist das Einfinden in da Spiel sehr gut gemacht.
11.: Zwar wohl kein Open World aber abzulaufen um ein paar Goodies abzugreifen ist da. (Man freut sich diebisch wenn man wa gefunden hat was nicht auf der Karte ist.)
12.: Kann ich echt empfehlen! War ja ein "Form" Fan und darÃ¼ber kam nichts. Ich revediere meine Meinung.
Wer "Form" mal gespielt hat und eine "bodenstÃ¤ndige" Alternative sucht wird hier fÃ¼ndig.
Das Spiel macht einfach nur Laune, sogar am Abend knobble ich rum wie es wohl weiter geht.
Und das bei diesen Temperaturen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025002322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1788, 'last_played': 1559199046}
review: Puzzle games about spatial reasoning are easier in VR, where spatial perception is enhanced by head tracking and stereo vision, but they are also more fun. This is a very good adaptation of a 3D first-person discrete elements puzzle game. The story is interesting, but sadly has nothing left to reveal at the conclusion if you're been reading all the text logs. There are a few things that really should be fixed (entity movement speed  doesn't scale to user-selected VR comfort max player speed) and a few things that can't be fixed (magic holes in walls that somehow won't let object be picked up through them) but overall this is a solid puzzle game with a satisfying length.

As for rotation, it's about the same situation, snap turning or smooth turning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008307996', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1561651775}
review:
The short bit:

This is one of those games where the less you know about it, the better it will be.

It has physics puzzles, jigsaw puzzles, and some puzzles you really need to think outside the box to solve.

If you like those things, this is definitely worth a go.


The technical details:

i played with an oculus rift, and i did find i had to change graphic settings to swap the game from using Steamvr to using the oculus one in order to unlock the ability to jump, as some puzzles are impossible without it. bear this in mind if you have one also.

For movement, the game has some options you can choose, from basic point and teleport to classic analog, i did not get motion sickness from this but i ended up using teleport anyway simply because it was quicker, but i think this gave me an unfair advantage in time limited puzzles.

There is some comfort options to help those who get motion sick easily, but i ended up disabling them because all they really did was limit my vision and cause confusion with unexpected camera changes.

You can change the scale of the world, making the world smaller so you can reach higher things while sat down, which i did because i am too lazy to stand up, but could be a very helpful feature for those who cant stand up.


The negatives:

i had trouble with some puzzles, not because i couldn't figure them out, not because they were very complicated or difficult to pull off, but because the way the game lets you move objects can be unreliable.

It works by displaying a silhouette of the object you're holding where you point your controller, sometimes with the silhouette being directly on top of puzzle objects if you point at it.

I solved some puzzles way to early because for some reason an item i was trying to place ended up on a pressure plate behind a wall i couldn't see, opening up the prize room early and pretty much ruining the puzzle.

i ended up outright unable to solve some puzzles because an item phased through a wall after being placed and ended up out of the map bounds, and sometimes even inside a different puzzle room, making that one stupidly easy.

i spent way too long on simple puzzles because the item just would not plant where i wanted, even though it's placement silhouette is where i wanted it. 
[spoiler]Moving platforms are unnecessarily difficult to put items on[/spoiler]

Dispute these small yet highly infuriating problems, i still recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193343433', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1561022958}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039376989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3838, 'last_played': 1546203311}
review: solid game, one of the best VR titles I have played. Very pretty graphics, Interesting and sometimes difficult puzzles, with a lot of lore, and easter eggs to break things up. The puzzles could be frustrating, but for the most part they didn't make me want to cheat or look up the answer, but leave and come back later. It's open world so you can always try other puzzles and come back later. Often times I would come back and get it right away. You can even find workarounds on occasion. One gripe I have is that I played standing up, and all the reading and text dialog and tetris style puzzles became uncomfortable even exhausting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049165831', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1556732792}

author: {'steamid': '76561198288914820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1562429442}
review:
Purchased game in anticipation of using my new index controllers with it, but appears completely broken with them (hands don't even show up).  This game is still listed on valve's controller page as a game with special updates to "take advantage of the new controllers for launch" 

Solid game otherwise.  Great environments, great puzzles!  Just know that your new controllers will not work at all even when mucking with the bindings yourself.

Update: Still no working support for Index Controllers with the latest update.  Controllers show up in game now which is new (not hands), but still are unresponsive and you can't click to start the game.

Update2: Had to trick the game by using one wand and one index controller and flip between different bindings before getting things to work...but they do seem OK now.  Index support still seems rather shaky.
developer_response:
Hi Phatfish,
sorry you were having issues. However, we just updated the game with Index support so please try after the update.

Cheers,
Danny

author: {'steamid': '76561198048263568', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1560451281}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016018595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1560348303}
review: bof

author: {'steamid': '76561198120070158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1674928666}
review:
"You've played 13 hours". 13 hours of which 12 hours are fiddling with the GPU settings. You think you have finally found a combination that is stutter free, then voila, next level and there is stuttering again.
I have a gtx 1070 but it should be able to handle TTP at decent settings, but any form of AA is out of the question so you have to love jaggies, and dynamic lightning is also out of the question regardless of if you put the settings at the lowest possible. 
It's funny because if you use the auto config then MSAA is enabled but with AA on the game is unplayable in any resolution.
The game itself is great, but the gaming experience is very far from fluid because of all the time you have to spend in the settings.
It's depressing that VR has been ruined by poor development. I haven't bought a VR game in a long time because I always read before buying and it's mostly the same story in reviews, poor performance regardless of what developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019146766', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1560283586}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032673579', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1559221979}
review:
Pro:
Ancient environment, esp. stone statues, look amazing in VR.
Also I liked the voice e.g. when trying to leave the island by sea, add immersion.

Cons:
Puzzles are too simple (I'm at 25% of the game currently as much as I can judge).
But that's enough & relaxing, I love just to walk there, even check e-mails from dusty computers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967448717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1574623521}
review: looks good play's well in VR  good story .

author: {'steamid': '76561197993531965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1545535319}
review:
Pretty straight forward... It's the Talos Principle in VR
I only have this version of the game and I don't regret it.
Not much to do except the puzzles and explore the small islands. But it's still fun.
The story tidbits are amusing to read and pop up on terminals and hidden plaques and other terminals in the various zones.
Boils down to a "fruit of the forbidden tree" story very quickly, but its got a nice feel to it and it doesn't seem forced.
I use an Oculus Rift with touch controllers and the interface works just fine without issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962741350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1036, 'last_played': 1553903423}
review:
I bought this without knowing anything about the game. As a VR puzzle game this is excellent. The use of force fields, lasers, drones, and time travel really work well together. The scenery is also quite beautiful, the mix of technology in the historical settings is quirky but interesting.

However the story is utter trash.

I completed the game and I enjoyed the increasing challenge of the puzzles. I couldn't care less about the spiritual/existential/deity nonsense in the story. I probably won't play the DLC because of this, nor would I be interested in the rumoured sequel.

Despite my positive recommendation for the VR puzzles, I would never have bought the game if I knew about the story. A different, modern style like the Portal games would have much better suited these technology based puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198850989281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1619333345}
review: I'm about 80% through and really liking this game. The puzzles increase in difficulty at a rate that always keeps me engaged. I haven't played the non-VR version before so I can't make a comparison between the two, but I can say I haven't encountered any bugs in 14 hours of playing and the whole experience feels really natural and immersive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052633453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1552833202}
review:
It gave me a massive headache and I felt dizzy after playing it for like few hours. Strange as no VR game has done that to me before and I tried quite a few.

Having said that (and it will not affect my review rating) the game did not impress me at all. I only have nearly an hour on clock but beat many puzzles during this time which were very easy and I did not enjoy them at all - they did not give a grain of satisfaction after resolving. 

Maybe puzzle games just aren't my thing. The game started off okay but then was very boring and repetitive. Don't understand the hype at all.


Not my cup of tea.


3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197996000877', 'num_games_owned': 636, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1554154670}
review:
This game is stellar, and the VR port of this game has every single accessibility option you could ever want. Teleport controls, regular movement, smooth turning, snap turning. Friendly to left-handed people, too.

However, it remains a VR port. Having it in VR does not add all that much to the experience. Still, it sure as hell beats the VR tech demos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964636851', 'num_games_owned': 2864, 'num_reviews': 411, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1552420443}
review:
+Great puzzles
+Lots of content
+Nice port

-Expensive even if you own original game
-Little buggy

4/5

If you can get on sale, or don't mind the price, I highly recommend this puzzle game. There's tons of content, and the puzzles just seem to get more and more difficult. Although they're never "Too" Difficult, just sometimes you have to think outside of the box a little more than most do.

If you liked this review [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33220185-VR-Games-and-Tools/]Click here[/url] and follow for more reviews of VR titles. And [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/HonestVR/]Click here[/url] if you want to request reviews on other VR titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025871186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2425, 'last_played': 1656669935}
review:
Fantastic. Puzzles along the lines of Obduction.

Only word of warning - ensure your CPU is spec'd in line with your video card. This game requires a decent CPU.

To run this game in Ultra all round at 90FPS, I had to update to a 1080ti and i5 9600k.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039915165', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1577401984}
review: This is a great game so far; first zen vr game that I found truly fun and refreshing to play. The puzzle made me actually think a little bit so far :D but none too hard yet. I am hoping one stumps me for a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129771193', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 2714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2019, 'last_played': 1557540196}
review:
Quite a good puzzle game. It's a port to VR, but still makes use of motion controllers. Given that it's a puzzle game though, the additional immersiveness of VR doesn't add as much to the game as something like Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice. It's still worth playing in VR, but I wouldn't bother buying the VR version if you already have the non-VR version.

A warning for achievement hunters: leaving the terminals till the end may make it faster to get all achievements, but the game is *much* more enjoyable if you read them as you go.

Pros:
- Uses tracked motion controllers
- Movement is heavily customizable, supporting both teleport and traditional movement, snap and smooth turning, and reducing FOV to prevent motion sickness
- Includes the DLC
- The difficulty curve from easy puzzles to harder ones is good
- Lots to explore and find, with multiple endings possible
- There are backups automatically created that you can restore to get other ends/achievements without having to replay the whole game
- I thoroughly enjoyed the story, especially the audio logs
- Road to Gehenna is a brilliant addition

Cons:
- I found the elevator buttons to be really finicky to push
- Towards the end the tetromino puzzles get really large and difficult. Personally I didn't enjoy them so I ended up just using a guide to get past them. I'm not sure how this could be improved though.

Verdict: 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197989784474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1577695248}
review:
No Journal in the VR version while still having prompts telling you that something is now available in the Journal is a slap in the face.

Also no button remapping is really annoying as the grab is mapped to triggers while every other Oculus thing has it in the grip buttons.

Together with all the little annoyances like this it doesn't feel like a finished product.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084611990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1619642430}
review: Es un juego que engancha. Los puzzles son muy buenos y originales, y el mundo por el que te mueves es enorme, empieza siendo reducido, pero cada vez se agranda mÃ¡s y mÃ¡s conforme descubres la historia. Muy recomendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127450166', 'num_games_owned': 744, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1551805276}
review:
Great game. I played a few houres of the non-VR and absolutely loved it. Then i saw this game on sale and also saw that the Serious Sam VR bundle (Which i was going to buy) was only 50cents cheaper than the Croteam VR bundle that included all Serious Sam VR games + The Talos Principle VR so i thought i might give it a try in VR. Teleportation weirdly gave me a headache but walking locomotion works fine for me.
It allows you to transfer over your Non-VR save (only from non-VR to VR and not in the other direction). 
The VR version feels way better. The immersion you get from VR is great for puzzle games (epecially ones that look this great) and it is all portet perfectly.
I don't know how long the game is but it is a port from a non-VR game so it is on the longer side (I played 5 houres and am no where near the end). The VR version also adds the DLC "Road to Gehenna" for free.
It would honestly be worth the asking price for me but if you are sceptical you can wait for a sale (it is usually around 5â‚¬ 
when its on sale)
A must have for anyone who like puzzle games (i got it because i loved solving puzzles in Portal) and it gets quite challenging at times (Eventhough I'm only 5 houres in). I dont want to talk too much about the story but lets just say it gives you something to think about when you are stuck in puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972374662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1680576094}
review:
I'm going to make this easy.  
Like puzzles, but not puzzle rooms?  
Like being plopped in the middle of a story with no idea who, what or why you are?
Like smooth running VR games that don't involve jumpscares or running like hell from demons?
Like a little philosophy in your games?

Then buy this game.  Now.
Then prepared to get lost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142551628', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2066, 'last_played': 1700233376}
review:
This is a really enjoyable logic puzzle game that works great in VR. The game is huge compared to many VR offerings! I found some of the puzzles very tricky but not utterly impossible. There was always a feeling that if you took a break and rethought it, you'd eventually get there.

There's also an interesting back story and reason for you being in the game that's told through clues left on terminals  that are scattered throughout the world.

I totally recommend the game for all VR users.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013258260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3393, 'last_played': 1697758307}
review: I got this in the bundle on sale but after playing it  I would pay way more if I did not luck out. Great game with hours of game play. Puzzles range in dfficulty from very easy to hard. Several times I finished a puzzle and thought how did I not get this way sooner. Music/soundtrack was repetative without seaming so and was very good at setting the mood. I can't judge the story as I did not dive deeply into it. I liked the way they story or narative was delivered and I plan to spend a bunch more time in the vr game even after finishing it. Some have complained about the control scheam but I was using WMR and found it very easy to control there are some changes available in the options menu if you want to find somthing more suited to your liking. I doubt they will read this but Thank you to all the people responsible for creating this game and to those who put in the effort to getting running in VR. Job well done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345553779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1548104788}
review:
The Talos Principle is a game I really like. Although not exactly free of violence it offers several days of more and more challenging puzzles, realistic graphics which I liked, quite a few things to think about and an interesting background story ... oh, and quite a few funny easter eggs. Almost the perfect game for me.

It's also one of few games offered as VR and non-VR version. I'll concentrate on the question whether bying the VR version is worth the money. Short answer is: Not bad but I prefer the non-VR version.

[u]In detail:[/u]
The developers at Croteam have created a rock-solid VR implementation of the original game. In contrast to other VR games I did not encounter any technical issues with the controllers, startup issues or such with my Windows MR headset. Moreover they offer an astonishing level of customization of the controls and the ways of movement. (I prefer continous movement, but discrete turing at 45Â° angles, for instance.) The game works smooth on my GeForce 1050 Ti with relatively high graphics settings (higher than auto-detected).

The VR experience however is mixed bag. Yes, the ability to look around is nice, but this is not needed often for the game itself. Certainly not when running through narrow corridors within puzzles. What's more important then is a snappy navigation. And that's a problem: If I don't configure different controllers I constantly inadvertedly turn instead of running straight, so I bump into walls too often. The discrete turning makes loosing orientation easy (but using continuous rotation makes me go crazy immediately). Given that in later levels movement speed and precision are crucial (e.g. when moving between hovering mines) the VR version makes the game harder than it should be.

What's more, some of the easter eggs where you pick things up [spoiler](such as a message in a bottle")[/spoiler] simply don't work for me with VR. The game doesn't let me grab anything from close to the ground. Poking the PC terminal's on/off switch with the finger is also less fun than it sounds. Grabbing or manipulating the environment doesn't feel half as convincing as in games like "Moss". 

Then there is this issue that the sky box is wrong (its actually closer than far-away trees or buildings). Not a big thing, and there is a thread with a simple fix for this from a user, but this should be corrected by Croteam together with Steam VR. Leaves or other small objects in the background seem to waver slightly and I found no graphics setting to improve this.

So what do you gain with VR? An only slightly more "immersive" feeling with 3D effect, but at the cost of a more difficult game-play, lower-resolution graphics and louder graphics card fans. And you have to wear these glasses for a long time to finish this game. I felt, I had enough after few hours.

Verdict: I recommend playing the non-VR version unless you need something to justify your VR glasses purchase ;-)

review: This is a deep and enthralling VR experience. For those of you who find pleasure in deep logic and yearn for a visceral VR world, go for this. It combines AI with philosophy, logic, and scenery in a breathtaking way. This blend makes VR essential rather than just an option for these types of games. Well done Croteam.

review: Part puzzle compilation, part exploration into philosophy.  The puzzles weren't too bad, but they increase in difficulty pretty swiftly near the end.  The narrative is very thought provoking, and the VR visuals for the final puzzles are pretty breathaking, though a "fear of heights" warning is probably warranted.  Still, great game and I'm glad I took the journey.  Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974428105', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1546136157}
review:
The Talos Principle is a great game. A truly spectacular piece of gaming craftmanship, and looking at the other reviews I appear to be in a minority, but I do not think this game has transferred to VR well at all. I went into this game expecting to relive the original Talos adventure and was left wanting. 

The original version let you smoothly walk through the world allowing you to slowly take in the world around you and let it sweep you up in it's tranquility. In contrast the lurching leaps of the teleport system totally shatterred this feeling for me making moving through the game world feel frantic and violent. WASD movement in the original game meant you could change direction quickly, you could strafe to look around corners from a safe difference. The games levels are perfectly designed and wonderfully envisioned, but they were never designed for VR movement systems. 

 The beauty of the mechanics of the original game was in it's simplicity, move around, pick things up, put them down. This simplicity is there in VR but means that there isn't much to do within the VR setting. You can play this game one handed if you want, sans the minor difference of a little bit of aiming with the various items.

The beauty in this game was always stunning but I was already stunned by the spaces the devs created to bring about this game, and while seeing the temple in VR was beautiful I had already been stunned, it was better but honestly? I had hoped for more.

The Talos Principle is a fantastic game. If you have never played it before, get it. Get it and with fresh eyes you probably won't see any of the problems I have and you will have a truly fun puzzler with an immensely touching story in your hands. If you have played and loved the original, you may find yourself immersed in the game in full 3D, but feeling less connected to it than ever. 

What a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013844936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1229, 'last_played': 1597504538}
review:
The motion controls for this game are superbly smooth. The devs obviously put a lot of time and effort into getting them right so that even a VR newbie like me can cope with the step locomotion. The locomotion configuration has lots of settings you can change independently of each other so you can set things up exactly the way you want them. The one complaint I have, and it is very minor, is that locomotion speed is hidden under game settings instead of VR controls. There donâ€™t seem to be any limits to roomscale support. I have a pretty small area, but I was able to move around inside it freely and even walk off ledges. Walking into a wall is pretty weird though. Talos doesnâ€™t let you clip through walls via roomscale, so it feels kind of like my brain ran into a wall even though the rest of me is still walking. This isnâ€™t a complaint, Talos handles walls well. Other games let you clip into or through walls, and it is terrible. Iâ€™m really impressed with how well locomotion was implemented in Talos; I wish all games would give their movement systems as much polish.

I spent most of the day playing it and havenâ€™t cleared all of the first set of puzzles yet, so it seems like thereâ€™s a fair amount of content. Some of the earlier puzzles were too easy; however, difficulty ramped up quickly. The primary puzzles in the game have to be solved to collect sigils. In addition to these puzzles, there are also much more difficult optional puzzles. These puzzles are not just hard, but theyâ€™re often hidden and the game doesnâ€™t inform you that they even exist until you solve the first. This is a great way to scale the puzzle difficulty so that players new to puzzle games can still enjoy the game and make progress while providing truly mind bending challenges for hardcore enthusiasts.

In addition to the two main puzzle types, there are also a number of messages secreted around the world adding an exploration and discovery layer on top of the puzzles. The challenge puzzles being largely hidden also provides an incentive to look in every nook and cranny.

The terrain looks gorgeous. Trees look like trees and grass looks like grass, even when you get up close. The sky just looks right for the most part and the way Talos handles horizons is fantastic. I donâ€™t want to spoil what happens when you try to walk off into the distance, but it completely fits the gameâ€™s tone. You definitely should give it a try when you play it. The sculpture and walls are admittedly lacking in detail, but that just means they support the narrative of being in an artificial world even better than they would if they looked entirely real.

Throughout, the developerâ€™s devotion to producing an excellent game shines through. There are so many fantastic little details. The popup display embedded in your wrist that tracks items you recover as you solve puzzles is genius. As are the signposts that indicate which puzzles have been solved and all the ways the game provides information about what areas have or have not been fully cleared while still encouraging exploring every nook and cranny.

Bottom line: I booted it up intending to play for just 15 minutes and only stopped playing an hour and a half later because I got hungry. This is VR done right. If you havenâ€™t played it yet, youâ€™re cheating yourself out of a fantastic experience.

review: Yes for the price yes. especially if you have a VR head set. Gives me a myst like vibe. Which we need for VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985851570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1631975581}
review:
Wow, just wow... I have had my eyes on this game for a long time but never could have imagined that it was this good. If I would have known then I would have bought it years ago. I can't remember when I was this awestruck by a game. Hats off to the developers!

UPDATE:
I just wanted to come back to my review and update my thoughts about it now that I finished playing the game. This game is like a book that you can't put away, a truly philosophical journey that goes beyond the puzzles and hits you with it's beautiful scenery, music score and atmosphere. Don't be in a hurry when playing this game, and definitely don't expect an action packed experience. This is all about tranquility and thoughtfulness. Sure, there are areas that this game can improve, like reduce the number of repetition of puzzles, and make the "story" a bit shorter so that it's possible to play it through in say sub 8 hours. It doesn't have to be long to be good.  Anyway, I will definitely return to this game again and finish it a second time since it will be like reading a good book or re-watching a good movie. A big thanks to the guys and girls behind this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198872343896', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2656, 'last_played': 1549665535}
review: Wow! This game should be a finalist for best VR Game. For sheer depth and value it's unbeatable right now. Well designed puzzles have kept me engrossed for two full days of VR pleasure. The difficulty gets harder with the more experience you gain, that continues to stretch you and there is huge satisfaction upon completing some of the more difficult levels. Great all-round game design which has been thoughtfully and carefully optimised for the VR version. Highly recommended and insane value in the sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140299850', 'num_games_owned': 2332, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 6908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2404, 'last_played': 1569230268}
review:
I intend to write something far more detailed about The Talos Principle VR soon, but I see several friends have this on their wishlist, and I feel the need to express something before the sale ends.

I played the regular version to the level of 22 achievements, and loved it very much (but accepted my limits.) But the VR version is a whole new ballgame, and I suspect I won't be quitting so easily this time. While the VR navigation takes a bit of getting use to (and I believe a tutorial not so much in movement, but in nuance would be VERY helpful) the "Talos World" is simply an amazing place, and one that I hate to ever leave. I'm not sure if my increased success is due to more puzzle game experience in the interim, or the fact that VR is simply more "there", but in A level alone I gained at least three sigils that eluded me before (and in fact have them all, and with zero assistance.)

Please, if the money is the issue, $6 (USD) is almost a gift in itself, and I think I can assure anyone wondering that they will never regret the expense. And if you played before, the experience alone is stunning enough to eliminate feelings of repetition.

Admittedly, I'm new to VR, but this is what I always fantasized that VR would be. All I have to do for maximum enjoyment is sit on the couch, and on rare occasions stand up for a little extra height. No effort, and a world I can believe in for an amazing price.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084674911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1545603656}
review: I SO wanted to like this game. It's a beautiful concept that, in my opinion, is very poorly executed.  The puzzles are challenging and for the most part fun and I wanted to know more!  But what makes this not recommended for me is the fact that you have to wander thru a freaking maze to find the puzzle doors/gateway/path.  On my first 45min play, I found it very annoying and felt that it detracted from the fun I had just had solving the puzzles.  I put the game aside and restarted my quest, to give it another shot, the next day.  Again, I found the puzzles very entertaining but the most time I spent in the game was going back and forth thru the maze to find the areas with the puzzle pieces I needed and then back to the main area to open a gate.  I found it all even more frustrating than the first time because this game would have been INFINITELY better without having to go thru that.  A simple, central portal or menu would have been perfect to get the player from section to section.  Very frustrating because I wanted to like it but ultimately, Refunded

author: {'steamid': '76561197973021945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1545532923}
review:
This is another situation where a game would be better served by a more nuanced rating system. I'm not giving a negative review because the game is trash. I'm giving a negative review because it's the honest answer to the question: "Do you recommend this game?" I do not. Here is why:

Movement is exactly the opposite of intuition--as is interaction:

Grip button to teleport; trigger to grab.

There is also no option to rebind these to be more logical.

Further, this is the first VR game where teleporting made me motion-sick. Usually the teleport option is to avoid motion sickness, but that doesn't work when there is stuttering in the middle.

And as a final insult, the teleport scheme itself is lousy--though perhaps I was just spoiled for teleporting systems because my first VR game was Robo Recall--but it makes for a good point of comparison to understand what makes The Talos Principle's teleporting so lousy.

In Robo Recall, you use the thumbsticks to set up your teleporting, with additional aiming by pointing. The thumbstick also serves to set what your facing will be at the end of the jump. This makes it simple and intuitive to BAMF! around, changing your facing to be what you want or need it to be at the other end of the jump. Teleporting three feet ahead but facing the opposite direction is effortless and natural.

Here, in The Talos Principle, your facing is locked during teleportation. To change facing, you use the thumbsticks. The default is to rotate in 45 degree increments.

For much of the game, that's fine, if a bit inconvenient. Where it falls apart is when you have to actively avoid a patrol--which happens pretty early on. It means that any action that requires you to outpace a threat more difficult, because your facing will be off--and you will likely find yourself getting turned around in real space because it's so much more instinctive to turn your body to deal with the problem.

That last probably isn't much of a problem if you have a roomscale setup. But if your play area is smaller, or if you're trying to play seated, it can be the difference between making it through a puzzle, and starting over. I only have a half hour of playtime, but in that time, it happened a couple times--I ended up being killed mid-puzzle because the controls were in my way.

This isn't exactly a frantic game. But it manages to be challenging in a similar manner simply because the controls don't work the way one might expect if you come from other VR games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078457883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1278, 'last_played': 1548093407}
review:
Edit after finishing:  This is going down as one of the best games I've played.  It fits VR like a glove and has great controls and movement.  Wish I got it much sooner than I did.
Original:  It has great environments and looks great in VR.  The puzzle mechanics work really well and it's awesome to be able to pick up the different puzzle parts to place them yourself.  Very relaxing atmosphere and a deep well thought out story.  Well done Croteam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015668388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1545340583}
review: I own the 2D version and I bought this on sale for $6. It is not worth it. It's terribly optimized so performance is bad. It stutters. No option to rebind controls. Pickup is with trigger, and worse jumping is with grips. Jumping with grips on oculus results in being afraid to fully hold the controller to avoid the many accidental presses. This can be fixed with Steam Input config but that kind of stuff shouldn't be necessary. I now have to use grips for in menu selection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055890746', 'num_games_owned': 1440, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1550641237}
review:
I wasn't 100% sold on the vanilla version.

As far as im concerned, VR is the only way to experience this. When I stood before the tower, it was so beautiful that I fell to my knees and cried. 

Controls are spot on. Not many VR games give you liberty to adjust most of the control scheme, but TTP is so simple and set up in such a way that doing anything just feels natural

As for the meat and potatoes, I don't think these guys need MY affirmation on how good the puzzles and game is as a whole

author: {'steamid': '76561198864412435', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1621699607}
review: the slow paced puzzle gameplay works amazingly in VR

author: {'steamid': '76561198066519590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1579343194}
review:
In short, if you want a smooth and fairly polished puzzle solving experience in VR and haven't bought the base game I highly recommend this at any price, else definitely worth it on sale!

After playing 40 odd hours of the non VR version of the game and it's DLC's, seeing this game on sale for 8 bucks AUD, for me it was a must buy! 
This game is amazing in VR, and although I am totally against its full price tag if you've already played the original, I highly recommend picking it up on sale as it's hands down the smoothest and most enjoyable puzzle solving VR experience I've ever had.

Also, for those of you complaining about movement speed, I'm not sure if it's a bug or not, but on the occulus rift holding down the jump trigger on both the left and right controllers will mute sound and send everything in game, including your movement speed, into fast forward by what feels like a good x2-x3, which definitely helps when you want to get back to an area quickly after dying and you're not at risk of missing dialogue in the process.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071445596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1706864262}
review: Cannot believe Talos Principle is in VR!!! The best game ever, even better in VR! The view is wonderful, the control is the best i've seen. Must play for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043226817', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1554660439}
review: The VR game is a perfect port of the original game. The immersion is very high and tho its only a puzzle game in VR its double the fun. The base game has a captivating story and upholds the excitement up until the endgame. The story of the expansion is not that funny, but ok. The game is good too to test some graphics APIs; in windows I can set the max scale factor of the VR to 2,0x on DX11 and DX12. With Vulkan tho on Linux I can go up until 3,0x before it starts lagging. Max setting is 4,0x what would need a 1080. With my 1060 tho in Linux and 3,0x its perfect, already beautiful @ 2,0x.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018686466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1544582091}
review: Talos Principle is even better in VR than my previous non-VR experience. Being able to teleport around the map is so much more convenient than walking back and forth to find the solution; and the ability to move your body around to examine angles and positioning is better than anything that you could do with a controller. It's one of the best VR games that I've played and fits the gameplay perfectly. And thankfully, the development team did an excellent job creating such a polished experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071253972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1510126092}
review:
Loved the game when it came out to PC, loved it even more in VR.

Being able to walk around the world and interact with the puzzles in VR is amazing. The developers did a fantastic job by providing so many locomotion options.

The VR version also includes the DLC version, so this is a great deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037348917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1524257207}
review:
Lightly edited from my non-VR version review

What if... God was real?

But instead of wanting you to be nice to other people, there were no other people and instead He wanted you to mess with Tetrisâ„¢ pieces in order to live forever?

That is the terrifying premise of The Talos Project. It is the best game of [strike]2014[/strike]2017[strike], or at least this December[/strike].
As shown in the promo images, this game also features two of my favorite things:

â€¢ Being a robot
â€¢ Petting a cat!!!

I've always wanted to be a robot, so it's pretty neat that I can do that in the game. No cats though! (Update: I found a cat, but I couldn't pet it :((( )

[spoiler]You can pet the cat![/spoiler]

It reminds me a little of the Mac game Marathon because of all the computer terminals. But in that game, you couldn't see if your hand were human hands, so if you were a robot or a cyborg was a mystery. The Talos Principal is better, because you can tell you are a robot right away, it's like the first thing that happens. Also, in the game you can type much faster and more accurately than I can in real life. I guess that's a third awesome feature!

â€¢ Typing quickly and accurately

I haven't finished yet, but if you like platform puzzles, reading about the nature of existence (Actual Kant excerpts in game, for real), and thinking about how sad the apocolypse is going to be, this is the game for you.

I give The Tavros Principle 10/10 "sigils" (Although it didn't manage to find the eleventh secret sigil)

PS: Dog is fine!

PPS: This includes Gehenna DLC?!? Crazy amount of value all-around. And for WMR folks, it includes graphics options for saturation and contrast that make the LCD HMDs look much better than by default.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017898795', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1591011690}
review:
Ich war sehr erfreut als ich gesehen habe dass The Talos Principle jetzt auch als VR zu erhalten ist und habe im Grunde genommen gar nicht Ã¼berlegt und es einfach gekauft. 
The Talos Principle hat mich schon als nicht-VR verblÃ¼fft. Obwohl das Croteam ja eigentlich mehr fÃ¼r das Wegballern von bÃ¶sen Aliens in allen Serious Sam Titeln verantwortlich ist, welche ich Ã¼brigens auch sehr gerne gespielt habe, zeigt The Talos Principle eine Ã¼berraschende Tiefe. Dabei geht es erstaunlicherweise gar nicht um das eigentliche Spiel welches durch seine durchaus anspruchsvollen Knobelaufgaben dazu reizt sich haufenweise NÃ¤chte ohne Schlaf um die Ohren zu hauen, sondern um die philosophisch angehauchte Hintergrundstory die sich in vielen PuzzlestÃ¼cken langsam zu einem vollstÃ¤ndigen Bild entwickelt.
Und Ã¤hnlich wie bei Serious Sam ist auch hier die VR-Variante sehr Ã¼berzeugend. Dabei kann ich gar nicht sagen woran das genau liegt, aber wenn man eigenlich nur mal in das Spiel rein schauen mÃ¶chte und dann kurz darauf merkt dass schon Ã¼ber eine Stunde um ist dann ist das meines Erachtens ein Zeichen dafÃ¼r dass die Entwickler irgendetwas richtig gemacht haben. Offensichtlich hat das Croteam bei der Umsetzung auf VR ein gutes HÃ¤ndchen. Ich freue mich auf jeden Fall darauf in der nÃ¤chsten Zeit einige Dinge in The Talos Principle VR auszuprobieren die ich in der nicht-VR Variante bisher nocht nicht gemacht habe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998105594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1541197315}
review: The only reason I'm not recommending this game is because there is a bug with the elevator and you can't leave the first area because of it. When you try to press the button it kinda freaks out and then nothing. I'm not sure if its just the VR controls not working properly with the buttons or the the anti-piracy feature with the elevators, but apparently it is not working correctly if it's preventing people who have a legit copy of the game from progressing. I would suggest buying the regular version of this game as it is less likely to have bugs like this, taking that its the VR controls that cause this issue. Another minor annoyance was that when you were interacting with the terminals your face is really close to the keyboard and it causes the text on the dialog options to become blurry and extremely difficult to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198176315502', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1547317122}
review:
best 18 bucks I spend, but full price is still worth it!!! this is a game where you can lose track of the time and spent many hours in. the devs put a lot of effort in this game. the graphics are amazing, the difficulty of puzzles is just about right. the story is very good.
from in the beginning, you want to now whats in the end.
this is a very relaxing game, and what I said earlier, you can lose track of time. so be carefull.
I recommend this game, even at full price!!! btw, this is the only game I would recommend even at full price. but if you are Like me, wait for a steam sale, you won't be disappointed ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198100189445', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1529212253}
review:
Really bad... Please people, try to design the game for  a decent VR experience if you are going to charge for it. It's not as simple as strapping the camera to the players face and handing them some shit ass controls, and voila! A sellable VR title!

I really wanted to like this game, but it physically hurts to play it, and I couldn't do it for long after a couple tries.

Try to make it better than bad. Because I would imagine that the non-VR version of the game is pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057680429', 'num_games_owned': 1126, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1536676585}
review:
I have never played The Talos Principle before. I am a huge fan of puzzle games. The Witness and Portal 2 are two of my favourite games of all time.

This isn't as nice looking as The Witness, and the puzzles might not be of the same creativity, but it is a great quality title so quench your Puzzling needs.
It takes a bit before the puzzles starts getting tricky, but it is worth it. Contrary to The Witness, this game has you unlocking new mechanics every now and then, which keeps the portal-esque gameplay feeling fresh.
The controls takes a bit getting used to, but it is really intuitive once you get the hang of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971078343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1536233620}
review:
I loved the game on the flat screen and was looking forward to playing in VR.

Unfortunately the port to VR made the game both difficult to play and unenjoyable, mostly due to the movement mechanics. This is the only VR game I have played that has induced nausia for me, and I have played other open world games without issue.

The game is graphically wonderful, and I was really hoping to use this as one of the examples of what VR can deliver when I have friends over to try my VR setup, but with the movement mechanics as they are at the moment, I would not do so.

Due to the poor porting I would not recommend the game in its current state.

(Reviewed using a Vive Pro system)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096220624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1583569094}
review: Vast and deep, fun puzzles and great narrative. Sometimes the puzzles are super simple, some take a little brainpower, and some make you want to open youtube and watch a tutorial because the last 30 minutes you spent trying to solve it isn't working.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977427464', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1570901452}
review:
If you haven't tried The Talos Principle and want to give it a go in VR, it's all here. You can do it.

It's a port, though, not built for VR, and it shows. It breaks some rules: get too close to a wall and it'll push you back, which can be very unsettling. Step down a ledge or up onto a step and it pushes you up or down, which might be even worse. The purple semi-transparent level barriers that are fine to walk through in 2D are disturbing and difficult to walk through in room-scale.

It has a good sense of scale, which is fine until you grab a jammer that's big enough to intersect with your actual body unless you hold it at arm's length, which is awkward and creepy. If you want to primarily walk by flipping your space around to line up with where you want to go - which can be really immersive - instead of blinking everywhere or using smooth locomotion, the locomotion options aren't super well-suited for that. It allows changing the distance covered by a snap turn, but you can't both cross a field (180 degree turns) and turn corners (90 degree turns) with a low number of turn presses without going back into the menu.

It's definitely still pretty, has a good sense of wide-open space. I was able to get down on the ground and stare at where the grass didn't meet up with the (beautiful and bumpy) brick wall, which was interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025531773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 4065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1561974708}
review: Works great on Oculus BTW. Everyone already knows that Talos Principle is a great game- I just want to chime in with that this game feels and looks great in VR. Like it was made for it. The conversion is top notch. Lots of settings to play with for GPUs of different capabilities. I like the feeling of being in Roman ruins, which seem pretty authentic to me. Love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975390135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1614426071}
review:
A fantastic puzzle game with a great story now playable in VR, this game acts as a beginners guide to philosophy and takes you through age old questions and possible answers. This is done through an easy to follow methodical order paced masterfully throughout the game. Between puzzles you will debate philosophy with the computer via multiple choice answers and in doing so unlock further dialogue which intertwines with the main story of the game. Worth playing either in or out of VR.

Graphics - Pretty good, can be a little grainy but overall good. 
Music - Absolutely Amazing and wonderfully atmospheric.
Gameplay - Puzzles start off simple and gradually become a challenge, combined with the music and setting the atmosphere of sitting trying to work out a puzzle is very satisfying which is only enhanced in VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996398849', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1532294926}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105133275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1530480600}
review:
I am genuinely surprised that this game has been rated so high. I think I know the problem:

VR is a new gimmick and as far as VR games go, it is OK. It's a puzzle game that at best might be worth Â£4.99. The problem is that the cost they are asking for this game (Â£30) is what you can get a AAA game for, remember this game is not new. You are paying a ridiculous amount of money for a game that is about 8 assets just copied and pasted into different levels. It's not bad, just in no way is it worth anything near the asking price. These devlopers think that because VR is a relatively new addition to gamers, they can charge what they want for mediocre looking games. 

Put it this way; I got Skyrim VR for Â£30 and it's phenomenal. Echo Arena is FREE and is so much more interactive and better than this. Now I think of it, I am getting a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993618549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2383, 'last_played': 1530152903}
review:
Don't buy the VR version. The normal version is probably pretty good though.

Because:
- Only a small percentage of the gameplay lends well to VR. Mostly it's standing around thinking. I can do that much more effectively without standing/sitting in the middle of the room with an HMD on.
- Certain puzzles are not solvable with normal VR locomotion.
- You may miss solutions to puzzles because of defects in the input system.
- You might go look up a solution and still struggle to accomplish a task that would probably be much easier without VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001872864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1523817909}
review:
I give The Talos Principle VR (Oculus Rift) 4.5/5 stars. This is quite a unique game with good graphics, nice atmosphere, somewhat challenging puzzles (and a lot of them). They even mix in some philosophy which I find is interesting and unique.

Areas for improvement:
1. Perhaps give the option to run or sprint - I find walking too slow
2. This game sometimes makes me feel nauseous after a long session - and I don't feel this way in too many other games. It's not bad though, fairly minor and only happens after an hour or two playing. 
3. Nothing else really - good puzzle game!

Positives:
1. Graphics are great
2. There are tons of puzzles, and they vary in difficulty. There are many different elements introduced to the puzzles over time
3. I like the computer terminals where you can read various philosophical writings and backstory

Bottom line: A must have for fans of puzzle games (like Portal). Pick up the Croteam pack when it's on sale - it's an amazing deal and you would also get the Serious Sam Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198832001481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 4569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1532865651}

author: {'steamid': '76561197978406355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 1191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1621179501}
review: I played the base game on the flat version, and just Road to Gehenna in this VR version. The puzzles are tougher in Gehenna, and there are even inventive new ways to use the old equipment to solve puzzles. VR smooth locomotion is well done. I recommend having a fallback activity planned so when you get stuck you can put the game down and come back later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1529302788}
review:
[h1] Experienced on the Oculus Rift with Touch Controllers [/h1]

One of the best VR experiences currently available. Even if you're not a fan of puzzle games, you will enjoy the immersion into this VR philosophical world questioning existence. There's a tactile feel to puzzles when you use motion controllers and can look around and be in the puzzle, not just see it on a screen.

This is a complete game. Your mileage will vary, but expect anywhere from 10-20 hours in this game. Puzzles start simple and slowly but surely get more complicated the further you go. You learn as you go on, like a child. The voice of God is well done and brings atmosphere to the puzzles. There's also a story to piece together by going to the terminals and input is done well by just touching the highlighted areas.

I already owned Talos Principle non-VR version and I'm so happy they brought this to VR. It just feels like a natural fit. I would say it's still worth purchasing even if you played this before. However, I do recommend changing the default controls. Enable full locomotion, smooth turning, and turn off comfort mode for the best VR experience. 

Rate 8.5/10. The best pure puzzle experience in VR (non-escape room).

Der VR Aspekt unterstÃ¼tzt die rÃ¤umliche Orientierung in dem Spiel und da das Spiel meist keine schnelle Reaktionen erfordert, kann man sich auch nicht in dem Vive Kabel verheddern.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971765334', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1527459687}
review:
One of the best more serious VR experiences out there. A must buy if you like first person puzzle games such as The Witness, Myst, Portal 1 and 2.

The narrative and philosophy is deep if you want it to be (accessed through optional terminals found throughout the world), based around what it means to be a person in a world of AI. If you like West World, you'll love this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963420289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 3606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1182, 'last_played': 1529953348}

author: {'steamid': '76561198114960835', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1676, 'last_played': 1553468053}
review: I... It just takes the words out of my mouth. This is a really fun and Immersive game. I would get headaches from the puzzles being hard but fun. It has feelings, it has puzzles, it has everything you would want in a sparked puzzle game thats hard and story telling all at the same time. The amount of endings that allow things to be revealed. The pure fact is that this game is a game that will fill you with questions and doubt about thoughts and some things. This is the game that gives questions but hard to know answers. The other thing I wish for is more DLC if possible. I mean the game is super long and awesome but I just wish that there was more of it to go around. I always get sad that I finish a really good game because most of the time a really good game allows me to connect with the characters and everything around it. The Talos Princple did the best at this. I felt very connected with The Serpent and Elohim and the puzzles. I finished the game after like a few months because the puzzles always got at me. If you like Puzzle, Scfi, and Story telling games, this is the best game to choose

author: {'steamid': '76561198027309793', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1545040995}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009816209', 'num_games_owned': 709, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1533936955}
review: I loved this game, it's a puzzle game and a port of the pancake version but it's really great in VR. The difficulty curve is amazing, it's always getting harder but you don't feel like any single puzzle is much harder than the last, so you keep trying until you get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007808181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1510347887}
review:
This game works well with VR input.  Never played the desktop version but the difficulty in puzzles start simple and slowly ramp up.  There's also collectable stars which act as a secondary collection objective.  These take some creative thinking, some luck in finding them, a much more difficult puzzling experience, and overall a much more rewarding experience once you collect them.

The narrative to the story also adds to the whole immersion of the game.  A good purchase if you enjoy puzzles.  Can't say anything about the replayability if you played the desktop version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025692762', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1534200646}
review:
A great VR port of a great game. Although not a native to VR game, the shear love Croteam put into porting this game into VR contrasts sharply to other developers (looking at you, Bethesda). Although some carryovers from the flat game can be a mild nuisance, such as being only able to carry one thing at a time, correcting those would require reworking gaming mechanics. It's a port, but a damn good one.

PS: take a stroll through the settings before you play, there is a happy abundance of movement options, and on my system the game was doing some odd things with autodetecting my graphic quality.
